revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox Election | election_name = Bhutanese general election, 2008 | country = Bhutan | type = parliamentary | ongoing = no | previous_election = | previous_year = | next_election = Bhutanese National Assembly election, 2013 | next_year = 2013 | seats_for_election = All 47 seats to the [[National Assembly of Bhutan|National Assembly]] | majority = 24 | election_date = 24 March 2008 | image1 = | leader1 = [[Jigme Thinley]] | party1 = Bhutan Peace and Prosperity Party | leaders_seat1 = Nanong-Shumar | seats1 = 45 | seat_change1 = | popular_vote1 = 169,490 | percentage1 = 67.04% | image2 = [[Image:Sangay Ngedup 2005.jpg|120px|Sangay Ngedup]] | leader2 = [[Sangay Ngedup]] | party2 = People's Democratic Party (Bhutan) | leaders_seat2 = Kabji-Talo
''(lost)'' | seats2 = 2 | seat_change2 = | popular_vote2 = 83,322 | percentage2 = 32.96% | map_image = Atlas-bhutan2008.gif | map_size = 350px | map_caption = Results of the Bhutanese Elections. | title = [[Prime Minister of Bhutan|Prime Minister]] | posttitle = [[Prime Minister of Bhutan|Prime Minister]]-designate | before_election = [[Kinzang Dorji]] | before_party = Nonpartisan | after_election = [[Jigme Thinley]] | after_party = Bhutan Peace and Prosperity Party }}{{Politics of Bhutan}} [[National Assembly of Bhutan|National Assembly]] elections were held in [[Bhutan]] for the first time on 24 March 2008.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7193818.stm |work=BBC NEWS |title=Main Bhutan election date is set |first=Subir |last=Bhaumik |date=17 January 2008 |accessdate=20 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081227045917/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7193818.stm| archivedate= 27 December 2008 | deadurl= no}} Two parties were registered by the Election Commission of Bhutan to contest the election: the [[Bhutan Peace and Prosperity Party]] (DPT, for ''[[Druk Phuensum Tshogpa]]''), which was formed by the merger of the previously established [[Bhutan People's United Party]] and [[All People's Party (Bhutan)|All People's Party]]{{cite news |url=http://www.bhutan.gov.bt/government/newsDetail.php?id=320 |work=Bhutan Portal |title=Druk Phuensum Tshogpa, the new party in town |date=25 July 2007 |accessdate=20 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080521073646/http://www.bhutan.gov.bt/government/newsDetail.php?id=320 |archivedate=21 May 2008 |df= }} and is led by [[Jigme Y. Thinley]], and the [[People's Democratic Party (Bhutan)|People's Democratic Party]] (PDP). The third political party, the [[Bhutan National Party]] (BNP),{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/003200705061012.htm |title=Bhutan gets third political party |work=The Hindu |date=6 May 2007 |accessdate=20 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080111080344/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/003200705061012.htm |archivedate=11 January 2008 |df= }} had its application for the registration canceled. ==Electoral system== The elections for the 47 seats of the National Assembly were planned to be held in two rounds: In the first round, voters would have voted for a party. The two parties with the largest share of the national vote would then have been able to field candidates in the 47 constituencies.{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/StoryPage.aspx?id=0fc17dd6-a4cd-4ccc-9dd4-e0fc571d7c02&&Headline=Caretaker+PM+appointed+in+Bhutan |title=Caretaker prime minister appointed in Bhutan |date=3 August 2007 |publisher=Indo-Asian News Service |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=20 November 2008}} However, as only two parties successfully registered for the election, the election was held in one round. ==Background== ===Mock elections=== On 21 April 2007, a [[mock election]] was held to prepare the population of Bhutan for the imminent change to democracy. These elections were held in all 47 National Assembly constituencies and at 869 polling stations with around 1,000 voters at each one of them.[http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/StoryPage.aspx?id=28cf6a1b-2ac2-429d-a56e-fbc4564dacf6& Bhutan set for mock elections on April 21] Hindustan Times, 20 April 2007 The parties "contesting" the election were the [[Druk]] Blue Party, the Druk Green Party, the Druk Red Party and the Druk Yellow Party (with ''Druk'' being [[dzongkha]] for "thunder dragon"), each of them representing certain values as their "party manifesto": yellow for traditional values, red for industrial development, blue for fairness and accountability, and green for the environment. The two parties winning the most votes were to proceed to a run-off election scheduled for 28 May.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6578421.stm Bhutan holds fake national poll] BBC News, 21 April 2007 Election observers were present from the [[United Nations]] and from [[India]].[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,21592367-2703,00.html Bhutan's election dummy run] The Australian, 21 April 2007 The results of the first round saw the Druk Yellow Party receive a plurality of the vote.[http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2007/4/22/worldupdates/2007-04-22T114127Z_01_NOOTR_RTRJONC_0_-295140-1&sec=Worldupdates Bhutan votes for tradition and monarchy in mock poll] The Star, 22 April 2007 {| class=wikitable style=text-align:right !Party !Votes !% |- |align=left|Druk Yellow Party||55,263||44.30 |- |align=left|Druk Red Party||25,423||20.38 |- |align=left|Druk Blue Party||25,295||20.28 |- |align=left|Druk Green Party||18,766||15.04 |- |align=left|'''Total'''||'''124,747'''||'''100''' |- |align=left|Registered voters/turnout||283,506||44.00 |} The two leading parties, Druk Yellow Party and Druk Red Party, put up randomly chosen high school students as candidates in the 47 constituencies in the second round on 28 May 2007. The Druk Yellow Party swept the vote and won 46 of the 47 constituencies. Turnout in the second round was 66%.[https://www.thestar.com/News/article/219222 Bhutan mock poll votes for tradition] The Star, 30 May 2007 283,506 people had registered to vote, though it is considered likely that a total of 400,000 would have been eligible to register as voters.[http://www.indiaenews.com/asia/20070528/53749.htm Encouraging turnout in Bhutan's historic mock polls] India eNews, 28 May 2007 ==Schedule== The election procedure began with the submission of the letters of intent, lists of candidates, copies of election manifestos and audited financial statements by the two political parties contesting the elections to the election commission followed by the release of the party manifestos by them on 22 January 2008.{{cite news |url=http://www.kuenselonline.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=9739 |title=March is on to Assembly Elections |work=Kuensel Newspaper |date=19 January 2008 |accessdate=11 December 2008}} From 31 January to 7 February 2008 both political parties submitted the nomination papers for their candidates for the 47 constituencies. The candidates, whose nominations were accepted, started campaigning in their constituencies from 7 February. The election campaign ended at 9:00 on 22 March. The last date for receiving the postal ballots was 18 February. The elections were held on 24 March from 09:00 to 17:00 followed by the counting of ballots on the same day. The results were declared on 25 March. All eligible voters were allowed to register with the election commission until 20 February 2008 for the inclusion of their names in the voters list which was updated to include those eligible voters who were eighteen years old on or before 1 January 2008. The final electoral roll was published on 5 March 2008. ==Results== {{Bhutanese general election, 2008}} Turnout reached nearly 80% by the time the polls closed, and the [[Bhutan Peace and Prosperity Party]] reportedly won 44 seats, with the [[People's Democratic Party (Bhutan)|People's Democratic Party]] winning only three seats (Phuentsholing in Chhukha, Goenkhatoe-Laya in Gasa and Sombeykha in Haa). The PDP's leader, [[Sangay Ngedup]], who was also the ruling king's uncle, lost his own constituency by 380 votes. Reportedly, there were few differences between the platforms of the two parties, which might explain the unexpectedly uneven results; analysts were worried that the small representation of the opposition might have obstructed the functioning of the newly founded democratic system, but this does not to appear to have happened, as power peacefully changed hands after the People's Democratic Party won the [[Bhutanese National Assembly election, 2013|2013 National Assembly elections]]. Both parties had pledged to follow the king's guidelines of "pursuing [[Gross National Happiness]]", and both party leaders had previously served in governments.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/25/world/asia/25bhutan.html |first=Somni |last=Sengupta |date=5 March 2008 |accessdate=20 November 2008 |title=Heavy Turnout in First Bhutan Election |work=The New York Times| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130301080749/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/25/world/asia/25bhutan.html| archivedate=1 March 2013| deadurl= no}} Another attempt to explain the BPPP's large-scale victory is that it is apparently the more royalist of the two parties.[http://www.nzz.ch/nachrichten/international/erdrutschsieg_der_royalisten_bei_den_wahlen_in_bhutan_1.694585.html Erdrutschsieg der Royalisten in Bhutan (International, NZZ Online)] (German) An explanation popularly given by Bhutanese in the days leading up to the election for the lack of support for the People's Democratic Party was that it would encourage corruption and be contrary to the King's request for the Bhutanese to form a popular government to elect leadership having (as was popularly believed about the PDP) strong personal ties to both the King and Bhutanese business. Due to a mistake in tallying the votes in [[Phuntsholing]],{{cite web|url=http://www.election-bhutan.org.bt/Docs/phuntsholing.pdf |accessdate=21 November 2008 |date=27 March 2008 |title=Results of the Phuentsholing Constituency of National Assembly Election 2008 under Chukha Dzongkhag |publisher=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028211916/http://www.election-bhutan.org.bt/Docs/phuntsholing.pdf |archivedate=28 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} it turned out that actually, the BPPP had won 45 seats and the PDP only 2.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSDEL16203420080327 |title=CORRECTED: Bhutan corrects poll results, opposition shrinks |work=Reuters |date=27 March 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008 | first=Bappa | last=Majumdar}} The two PDP members who were elected have refused to take up their seats and resigned their mandates, claiming that the civil servants informally campaigned for the DPT and thus greatly influenced the result.{{cite news |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/topNews/idINIndia-32738320080328 |title=Bhutan loses opposition as MPs cry foul over poll |work=Reuters India |date=28 March 2008 |accessdate=11 December 2008 |last=Denyer |first=Simon}}{{cite news |url=http://www.kuenselonline.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=10108 |work=Kuensel Newspaper |title=PDP asks ECB to investigate "very strange developments" before elections |date=29 March 2008 |accessdate=11 December 2008}} The DPT officially approved its leader as candidate for PM on 5 April 2008.{{cite news |url=http://www.kuenselonline.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=10149 |work=Kuensel Newspaper |title=DPT endorses Jigmi Y Thinley as Prime Minister |date=5 April 2008 |accessdate=11 December 2008}} He took office on 9 April.[http://www.hindu.com/2008/04/11/stories/2008041154161800.htm "Thinley takes over as Premier"], ''The Hindu'', 11 April 2008. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080326174207/http://www.bhutanobserver.bt/2008/bhutan-news/03/dpt-wins-by-landslide-national-assembly-election-results.html Election results] {{Bhutanese elections}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bhutanese General Election, 2008}} [[Category:Elections in Bhutan]] [[Category:2008 elections in Asia]] [[Category:2008 in Bhutan|General election]] [[Category:March 2008 events]] [[Category:First events]]

{{Infobox film | name = Boomerang! | image = Boomerang!.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Elia Kazan]] | producer = [[Louis de Rochemont]] | narrator = [[Reed Hadley]] | based on = {{based on|''The Perfect Case''
1945 article in
[[The Reader's Digest]]|[[Anthony Abbot]]}} | screenplay = [[Richard Murphy (screenwriter)|Richard Murphy]] | story = [[Fulton Oursler]] | starring = [[Dana Andrews]]
[[Jane Wyatt]]
[[Lee J. Cobb]] | music = [[David Buttolph]] | cinematography = [[Norbert Brodine]] | editing = [[Harmon Jones]] | studio = [[Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp.]] | distributor = Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp. | released = {{Film date|1947|03|05|United States}} | runtime = 88 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $1.14 millionSolomon, Aubrey (1989). ''Twentieth Century Fox: A Corporate and Financial History''. Lanham, Maryland: Scarecrow Press, p. 244, {{ISBN|978-0-8108-4244-1}}. | gross = $2.25 million {{small|(rentals)}}Solomon, Aubrey (1989). ''Twentieth Century Fox: A Corporate and Financial History''. Lanham, Maryland: Scarecrow Press, p. 222, {{ISBN|978-0-8108-4244-1}}.[https://archive.org/stream/variety169-1948-01#page/n62/mode/1up "Top Grossers of 1947", ''Variety'', 7 January 1948 p 63] }} '''''Boomerang!''''' is a 1947 American [[crime]] [[film noir]] based on the true story of a vagrant who was accused of murder, only to be found not guilty through the efforts of the prosecutor. It stars [[Dana Andrews]], [[Lee J. Cobb]], [[Karl Malden]], [[Arthur Kennedy]] and [[Jane Wyatt]]. The film was directed by [[Elia Kazan]], based on a story (written by [[Fulton Oursler]], credited as "Anthony Abbot") in ''[[Reader's Digest]]'' and was shot largely in [[Stamford, Connecticut]] after Kazan was denied permission to film in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]], where the actual events occurred."'Boomerang!,' shot in Stamford, to be screened in Bridgeport", ''The Advocate'' of Stamford, Connecticut, October 13, 2009 This [[semidocumentary]] also contains voice-overs by [[Reed Hadley]]. The film was entered into the [[1947 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/4223/year/1947.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Boomerang! |accessdate=February 19, 2011|work=festival-cannes.com}} ==Plot== Father Lambert (Wyrley Birch), a priest, is shot dead on a Bridgeport, Connecticut street at night. The police, led by Chief Robinson ([[Lee J. Cobb]]), fail to immediately find the murderer. It soon becomes a political hot potato, with the police accused of incompetence, and the city's reform-minded administration comes under attack. Robinson and the prosecutor Henry Harvey ([[Dana Andrews]]) come under severe pressure by political leaders to find the killer or bring in outside help. After strenuous efforts yield nothing, a vagrant ex-serviceman, John Waldron ([[Arthur Kennedy]]), is apprehended and identified in a [[Police lineup|lineup]]. He is interrogated for two days by police until, deprived of sleep, he confesses. The evidence seems solid, and a gun in his possession is believed to be the gun that was used in the shooting. Harvey, however, is not convinced. He questions Waldron, investigates the evidence and the witnesses. Harvey then risks his reputation and incurs the wrath of the police and the public in proposing that the defendant is innocent, while he and his wife ([[Jane Wyatt]]) are also being threatened by a businessman named Harris ([[Ed Begley]]). In court, even though he is the prosecutor, Harvey lays out the flaws in the case before the judge, and indicates he intends to dismiss the charges. The judge suspects Harvey's motives; Harvey's relationship with Chief Robinson is strained; and a mob unsuccessfully attempts to impose their own justice on Waldron. A sub-plot involving Paul Harris and a property under consideration for sale to the city—at a price Harris desperately needs to keep himself afloat—also has a prominent place in the film. Harris tries to blackmail Harvey by threatening to destroy his wife, a planning committee member, unless he supports the sale and sits idle, allowing Waldron to be convicted. At a preliminary hearing, Harvey once again presents evidence that would lead to Waldron's exoneration. When a reporter gets wind of the double-dealing and threatens Harris with exposure, Harris commits suicide in the courtroom. The film ends with a narration that the murder was never solved, and the real Henry Harvey was [[Homer Cummings]] who rose to the position of U.S. Attorney General. ==Cast== * [[Dana Andrews]] as State's Atty. Henry L. Harvey (the name used for the [[Homer Cummings]] character) * [[Jane Wyatt]] as Madge Harvey * [[Lee J. Cobb]] as Chief Harold F. "Robby" Robinson * [[Cara Williams]] as Irene Nelson (Waitress at Coney Island Cafe) * [[Arthur Kennedy]] as John Waldron (murder suspect) * [[Sam Levene]] as Dave Woods (reporter, 'Morning Record') * [[Taylor Holmes]] as T.M. Wade ('Morning Record' publisher) * [[Robert Keith (actor)|Robert Keith]] as "Mac" McCreery * [[Ed Begley]] as Paul Harris * [[Karl Malden]] as Det. Lt. White * [[William Challee]] as Stone, Harvey's assistant * Lewis Leverett as Whitney, Harvey's assistant * [[Arthur Miller]] as a suspect in the police line-up (uncredited) * Wyrley Birch as Father Lambert (uncredited) ==Background== ===Factual basis=== The film is based on an actual murder case in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]] in 1924. While walking near the Lyric Theatre in downtown Bridgeport, the Rev. Hubert Dahme ("Father George Lambert" in the film) was fatally shot behind the left ear by a gun fired at close range. Those in the theatre were so shocked that no one thought to call for an ambulance until 10 minutes had passed. Two hours later, the priest was pronounced dead at St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport. A vagrant and discharged soldier, [[Harold Israel]], was indicted for the murder. Israel confessed to the crime, and a .32 revolver was found in his possession that police believe was used in the murder. [[Fairfield County, Connecticut]] state's attorney [[Homer Cummings]] conducted a thorough investigation and found Israel innocent of the crime. Cummings (named "Henry Harvey" in the film) later became [[Attorney General]] of the [[United States]] under [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]. The ''Morning Record'' was the name used in the film for the ''Bridgeport Post'' (now the ''[[Connecticut Post]]''). ===Filming locations=== Almost all of the film was shot in [[Stamford, Connecticut]], except for the courtroom scene shot in [[White Plains, New York]].Russell, Don, "'Roles' in movies are nothing new for city: Kazan used Stamford in the '40s", editorial page column in ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'', Stamford edition, page A10, April 25, 2007 Stamford locations: * The [[South End of Stamford]], particularly at Saint Luke's Chapel. * Old Town Hall, particularly the Police Department offices and the stairway leading up from them to the courtroom. * The Altschul home on Den Road in Stamford (for a meeting of leading citizens). * For a scene in which the pastor was killed, the movie used the front and sidewalk of the Plaza Theatre, which stood on Greyrock Place (a driveway leading into the [[Stamford Town Center]] Mall is at that location now). * The former offices of ''[[The Advocate (Stamford)|The Advocate]]'' of Stamford, the local daily newspaper, on Atlantic Street. Some members of the ''Advocate'' editorial staff members were used in a scene about the news breaking that the priest killer had been caught. The movie premiered at the Palace Theatre in Stamford on March 5, 1947, with Kazan and Andrews in attendance. (Kazan later filmed ''[[Gentleman's Agreement]]'' which takes place in [[Darien, Connecticut]], adjacent to Stamford, and which also included the actress Jane Wyatt.) ==Reception== ===Critical response=== When first released film critic [[Bosley Crowther]] discussed the filmmaking, writing the "...style of presentation has resulted in a drama of rare clarity and punch."[https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9506E5D8103EEE3BBC4E53DFB566838C659EDE Crowther, Bosley]. ''The New York Times'', film review, March 6, 1947. Last accessed: Last accessed: February 19, 2011. The staff at ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the film a positive review and wrote, "''Boomerang!'' is gripping, real-life melodrama, told in semi-documentary style. Lensing was done on location at Stamford, Conn, the locale adding to realism. Based on a still unsolved murder case in Bridgeport, Conn, plot is backed up with strong cast...All the leads have the stamp of authenticities. The dialog and situations further the factual technique. Lee J. Cobb shows up strongly as chief detective, harassed by press and politicians alike while trying to carry out his duties. Arthur Kennedy is great as the law's suspect."[http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117789437.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&p=0 ''Variety''.] Film Review, March 5, 1947. Last accessed: November 26, 2009. ===Awards and honors=== '''Wins''' * [[National Board of Review]]: NBR Award, Best Director, Elia Kazan; 1947. * [[New York Film Critics Circle Awards]]: NYFCC Award Best Director, Elia Kazan; 1947. '''Nominations''' * [[Academy Awards]]: Oscar, Best Writing, Screenplay, Richard Murphy; 1947. The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists: * 2001: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Thrills]] – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/thrills400.pdf |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Thrills Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=August 20, 2016}} ==Adaptations to other media== ''Boomerang!'' was dramatized as a half-hour radio play on the November 10, 1947 broadcast of ''[[The Screen Guild Theater]]'' with Dana Andrews and Jane Wyatt, on the January 14, 1949 broadcast of the [[Ford Theatre]] with Dana Andrews and lastly, on ''Hollywood Sound Stage'' with [[Tyrone Power]] and [[Jane Wyatt]] on February 28, 1952.[http://www.digitaldeliftp.com/DigitalDeliToo/dd2jb-Screen-Guild.html#Hollywood_Sound_Stage The Screen Guild Programs] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511172837/http://www.digitaldeliftp.com/DigitalDeliToo/dd2jb-Screen-Guild.html#Hollywood_Sound_Stage |date=May 11, 2011 }} web site. Last accessed: February 19, 2011. ==See also== * [[Harold Israel]] * [[Homer Stille Cummings]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{AFI film|id=25091|title=Boomerang!}} * {{IMDb title|id=0039208|title=Boomerang!}} * {{Allmovie title|id=85653|title=Boomerang!}} * {{Tcmdb title|id=69356|title=Boomerang!}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100331175832/http://www.dvdbeaver.com/film/DVDReviews22/boomerang_dvd_review.htm ''Boomerang!''] at DVD Beaver (includes images) * {{YouTube|ScTz8zcvaZA|''Boomerang!'' film review by John Farr}} {{Elia Kazan}} [[Category:1947 films]] [[Category:1940s crime films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Docudramas]] [[Category:Films about miscarriage of justice]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Film noir]] [[Category:Films directed by Elia Kazan]] [[Category:Films set in Connecticut]] [[Category:Films shot in Connecticut]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:20th Century Fox films]]

A '''card not present transaction''' ('''CNP''', '''MO/TO''', '''Mail Order / Telephone Order''', '''MOTOEC''') is a [[payment card]] transaction made where the cardholder does not or cannot physically present the card for a merchant's visual examination at the time that an order is given and payment effected. It is most commonly used for payments made over [[Internet]], but also mail-order transactions by mail or [[fax]], or over the [[telephone]].
Card not present transactions are a major route for [[credit card fraud]], because it is difficult for a merchant to verify that the actual cardholder is indeed authorizing a purchase.
If a fraudulent CNP transaction is reported, the [[acquiring bank]] hosting the [[merchant account]] that received the money from the fraudulent transaction must make restitution to the cardholder - this is called a [[chargeback]]. This is opposed to a card present transaction, when the issuer of the card is liable for restitution.<ref name=cents>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=$9 Here, 20 Cents There and a Credit-Card Lawsuit |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/22/business/22digi.html?_r=1&src=me&ref=business |quote=If a credit card is physically swiped in the transaction, the bank that issued the card is on the hook for fraudulent charges. If it is a phone or Internet purchase — called a card-not-present transaction — the bank that hosted the merchant account that received the ill-gotten charges must make restitution, said Ms. Litan, the Gartner analyst. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 21, 2010 |accessdate=2010-08-24 | first=Randall | last=Stross}}</ref> Because of the greater risk, some card issuers charge a greater transaction fee to merchants who routinely handle card not present transactions.
The [[card security code]]<ref name="pc" /><ref name="crn" />{{Failed verification|date=January 2018|reason=Sources don't mention security codes etc.}} (commonly CVV2) system has been set up to reduce the incidence of credit card fraud arising from CNP.
==Mail-order fraud== {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2012}} If a card is not physically present when a customer makes a purchase, the merchant must rely on the cardholder, or someone purporting to be so, presenting card information indirectly, whether by mail, telephone or over the Internet.
[[Shipping companies]] may guarantee delivery of goods to a location, but they are normally not required to check identification and they are usually not involved in processing payments for the merchandise. A common preventive measure for merchants is to allow shipment only to an address approved by the cardholder, and merchant banking systems offer simple methods of verifying this information. Before this and similar countermeasures were introduced, mail order [[Carding (fraud)|carding]] was rampant as early as 1992. A ''carder'' would obtain the credit card information for a local resident and then intercept delivery of the illegitimately purchased merchandise at the shipping address, often by staking out the porch of the residence.
Small transactions generally undergo less scrutiny, and are less likely to be investigated by either the card issuer or the merchant. CNP merchants must take extra precaution against fraud exposure and associated losses, and they pay higher rates for the privilege of accepting cards. Fraudsters bet on the fact that many fraud prevention features are not used for small transactions.
Merchant associations have developed some prevention measures, such as single-use card numbers, but these have not met with much success. Customers expect to be able to use their credit card without any hassles, and have little incentive to pursue additional security due to laws limiting customer liability in the event of fraud. Merchants can implement these prevention measures but risk losing business if the customer chooses not to use the measures.
==Fraud== {{main|Carding (fraud)}} The United States [[Federal Trade Commission]] uncovered an operation running from 2006 to 2010 that netted more than $10 million in fraudulent charges on [[Credit card|credit]] and [[debit cards]]. The perpetrators used more than 100 [[merchant account]]s that they had created to do the billing.<ref name=cents/><ref name=pc>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=FTC Says Scammers Stole Millions, Using Virtual Companies |url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/199952/ftc_says_scammers_stole_millions_using_virtual_companies.html |quote=The scammers stayed under the radar by charging very small amounts — typically between $0.25 and $9 per card — and by setting up more than 100 bogus companies to process the transactions. ... According to the FTC, the fraudsters charged 1.35 million credit cards a total of $9.5 million, but only 78,724 of these fake charges were ever noticed. |work=[[PC World (magazine)|PCWorld]] |date=June 27, 2010 |accessdate=2010-08-25 }}</ref>
Each merchant account was attached to an [[Employer Identification Number]] belonging to a real merchant with a similar-sounding name.<ref name=pc/><ref name=crn/>
Each merchant account was tied to an 800-number from CallMe800.<ref name=pc/> Each account was also tied to a website they had created. They also rented physical addresses from companies which rent [[virtual offices]], such as [[IWG plc|formerly Regus]], for each merchant account. These virtual office companies, which did not know of and were otherwise not involved in the [[Confidence trick|scam]], would then forward any mail received at the virtual office to Earth Class Mail, a [[digital mailroom]] service that scanned mail from the physical address of the merchant account and forwarded it as a [[PDF]] to [[email]] accounts that the scammers had established.<ref name=cents/><ref name=pc/> The scammers also ensured that when they checked their online merchant accounts, that they used an [[IP address]] located near the billing address so as not to arouse suspicion.<ref name=pc/>
A charge of $9 was processed on about one million credit cards over the four-year period.<ref name=pc/> Each card was billed a single time. Credit card companies only investigate if the charge is more than $10 because it costs about that much to run an investigation. Then the money was moved to bank accounts in Lithuania, Estonia, Latvia, Bulgaria, Cyprus, and Kyrgyzstan where the money could not be traced or recovered. The perpetrators experimented with a 20-cent charge and that generated more suspicion than the $9 charge.<ref name=cents/> Only about 10 percent of the fraudulent charges were ever reported or contested by the card owner that was billed.<ref name=pc/><ref name=crn>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=FTC Cracks Down On Micropayment Credit Card Scam |url=http://www.crn.com/news/security/225701708/ftc-cracks-down-on-micropayment-credit-card-scam.htm |quote=Altogether, the thieves charged a total of $9.5 million from a total of 1.35 million compromised cards over a period of four years starting in 2006. However, only about 10 percent of the fraudulent charges were ever reported or contested, according to the FTC. |work=[[CRN Magazine|CRN]] |date= June 28, 1010|accessdate=2010-08-25 }}</ref>

{{Italic title}} {{refimprove|date=May 2014}} '''''Casus foederis''''' (or '''''casus fœderis''''') is derived from the [[Latin]] for "case for the alliance". In [[Diplomacy|diplomatic]] terms, it describes a situation in which the terms of an alliance come into play, such as one nation being attacked by another.
== Historical examples == === War of the Pacific === {{see also|Treaty of Defensive Alliance (Bolivia–Peru)}} In the [[War of the Pacific]], Bolivia invoked ''casus foederis'' to bring Peru into the war after Chile reinvaded Bolivia's coast. In 1879 Chilean armed forces occupied the port city of Antofagasta, after a Bolivian threat to confiscate the Chilean Antofagasta Nitrate Company's property. Peru attempted to mediate, but when Bolivia announced that a state of war existed, the situation deteriorated. Bolivia called on Peru to activate their secret mutual defense pact, whereas Chile demanded that Peru immediately declare its neutrality. On April 5, Chile declared war on both nations. The following day, Peru responded by acknowledging the casus foederis.
===World War I=== In [[World War I]], the treaties between [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Italy]] and [[Austria-Hungary]], and [[Romania]], which purported to require Italy and Romania to come to Austria's aid if Austria was attacked by another nation, were ignored by both Italy or Romania because, as [[Winston Churchill]] wrote, "the casus fœderis had not arisen" since the attacks on Austria had not been "unprovoked."<ref>Winston Churchill, The World Crisis at 572 (Abridged -- Free Press 2005).</ref>
===NATO=== [[North Atlantic Treaty#Article 5|Article 5]] of the [[NATO|North Atlantic Treaty]] governs mutual defense in the event of an attack on a member nation. It has been invoked only once: on September 12, 2001, in response to the [[September 11 attacks]] on the [[United States]].<ref>[http://www.nato.int/docu/review/2006/issue2/english/art2.html Invoking Article 5] ''NATO Review.''</ref>
== See also ==
* ''[[Casus belli]]'' * [[List of Latin phrases]]

The [[University College Dublin]] '''Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation''' (UCD '''CCI''') is a centre for research and education in [[Computer security|cybersecurity]], [[Computer crime|cybercrime]] and [[digital forensics|digital forensic science]] in [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]].
The UCD Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation was established in the early 2000s, and has developed collaborative relationships with law enforcement and industry from across the world. The Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation is widely regarded as Europe's leading centre for research and education in cybersecurity, cybercrime and digital forensics. UCD CCI trains specialist officers from the Irish national police service, An [[Garda Síochána]], Irish military personnel from the [[Defence Forces (Ireland)|Defence Forces]], as well as international law enforcement agencies [[Interpol]] and [[Europol]], and authorities from over 40 countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=About CCI|url=http://www.ucd.ie/cci/about_cci.html|publisher=Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation, University College Dublin|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> The CCI also runs educational qualifications and training for the industry sector and [[multinational corporation]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Masters Degree in Forensic Computing and Cybercrime Investigation at UCD|url=http://www.garda.ie/Controller.aspx?Page=7973|publisher=Garda Síochána|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref><ref name='a1'>{{cite web|title=Welcome message from Professor Joe Carthy, Director of UCD CCI|url=http://www.ucd.ie/cci/aboutcci/directors_welcome.html|publisher=Copyright Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation, University College Dublin|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref>
There is a Memorandum of Understanding between the Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation at UCD and the [[National Cyber Security Centre (Ireland)|National Cyber Security Centre]] (NCSC) at the [[Department of Communications, Climate Action and Environment|DCCAE]], the Irish government's computer emergency response team.<ref>{{cite web|title=Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation, University College Dublin|url=http://www.ucd.ie/cci/|publisher=UCD|accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Gordon|title=Cyber security a safe bet for growth|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/cyber-security-a-safe-bet-for-growth-1.1279774|accessdate=8 July 2015|publisher=The Irish Times|date=28 January 2011}}</ref>
UCD CCI has a network of formal relationships with the Garda Síochána, Irish Defence Forces, INTERPOL, Europol, [[Visa Inc.]], the [[Irish Banking Federation]], as well as collaborations with the [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] (UNODC), the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] (OSCE), [[European Anti-fraud Office|European Anti-Fraud Office]] (OLAF), [[Microsoft]], [[Citibank]] and [[eBay]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Projects|url=http://www.ucd.ie/cci/projects.html|publisher=Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation, University College Dublin|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Connolly|first1=Phillip|title=UCD to lead EU cybercrime project|url=http://www.businesspost.ie/#!story/Home/News/UCD+to+lead+EU+cybercrime+project/id/19410615-5218-5064-3d5b-c15900868938|accessdate=19 September 2015|publisher=The Sunday Business Post|date=27 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Current Projects|url=http://www.ucd.ie/cci/projects/current_projects.html|publisher=Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation, University College Dublin|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About CCI / Background|url=http://www.ucd.ie/cci/aboutcci/background.html|publisher=Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation, University College Dublin|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref>
The Director of the UCD Centre for Cybersecurity and Cybercrime Investigation is Professor Joe Carthy BSc., PhD.<ref name='a1'/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Gordon|title=Cybercrime costs businesses €240,000|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/cybercrime-costs-businesses-240-000-1.2261510|accessdate=19 September 2015|publisher=The Irish Times|date=25 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Ryan|first1=Nicky|title=The Government is thinking up new ways to stop you from being hacked|url=http://businessetc.thejournal.ie/government-cyber-security-measures-2051578-Apr2015/|accessdate=19 September 2015|publisher=Business Etc|date=19 April 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[National Cyber Security Centre (Ireland)|National Cyber Security Centre]] (NCSC) * [[Garda Bureau of Fraud Investigation]] (GBFI) * [[CIS Corps (Ireland)|Communications and Information Services Corps]] (CIS)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ucd.ie/cci/ University College Dublin (UCD) Centre for Cybersecurity & Cybercrime Investigation (CCI)]

[[File:Eisteddfod 1991.jpg|thumb|[[Robin Llwyd ab Owain]] chaired in 1991]] The '''Chairing of the Bard''' ({{Lang-cy| Cadeirio'r Bardd}}) is one of the most important events in the [[Wales|Welsh]] [[eisteddfod]] tradition. The most famous chairing ceremony takes place at the [[National Eisteddfod of Wales]], and is always on the Friday afternoon of Eisteddfod week.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/northwest/sites/eisteddfod/pages/history.shtml|title= Eisteddfod History|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= BBC|publisher= |access-date= 7 January 2014|quote=}}</ref> Winners are referred to as ''[[Prifardd|Y Prifardd]]'' (literally "The Chief Bard"). The custom of chairing the bard is, however, much older than the modern eisteddfod ceremony, and is known to have taken place as early as 1176.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/896/|title= The Chairing Ceremony|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= National Museum of Wales|publisher= |access-date= 7 January 2014|quote=}}</ref>
[[File:Eisteddfod Genedlaethol Cymru, Glynebwy, 1958.jpg|thumb|left|The chairing ceremony of the 1958 National Eisteddfod; the victorious poet was [[T. Llew Jones]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/arts-culture-news/national-eisteddfod-celebrates-100th-anniversary-9806080|title= National Eisteddfod celebrates the 100th anniversary of the birth of celebrated writer T. Llew Jones|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= Wales Online|publisher= |access-date= 6 April 2016|quote=}}</ref>]]
A new bardic chair is specially designed and made for each eisteddfod and is awarded to the winning entrant in the competition for the "[[awdl]]", poetry written in a strict metre form known as [[cynghanedd]]. It is possible for the chair to be withheld, if the standard of entries is not considered high enough by the judges. This was the case in 1889, when a chair made for a minor eisteddfod at [[Bagillt]], in Flintshire, was not awarded. The chair in question made news in 2006, when it was returned to Wales after being acquired by a local Welsh society in Canada.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/north_east/6033639.stm |title= Bardic chair returns to village|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= BBC News|publisher= |access-date= 6 April 2016|quote=}}</ref> This happened most recently in 2013 at the Eisteddfod in [[Denbighshire]], [[Gwynedd]].<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-23638996</ref>
The National Eisteddfod ceremony is presided over by the [[Archdruid]], who reads the judges' comments before announcing the identity of the bard, using only the [[nom de plume]] that the winner has used to submit the work. Up to this point, no one knows the true identity of the bard, who is asked to stand and is then escorted to the stage. Local children perform a dance to honour the new bard.
In 1917, [[Hedd Wyn]] (Ellis Humphrey Evans) was awarded the Chair for his [[ode]] "Yr Arwr" ("The Hero"). On 6 September 1917, when the ceremony of Chairing of the Bard took place at the National Eisteddfod, held at [[Birkenhead Park]], [[England]], the adjudicators announced that the winning entry had been submitted under the pseudonym ''[[Fleur de Lys]]''. After the trumpets had summoned the winner three times to stand forth from the audience, [[Archdruid]] [[Evan Rees (Dyfed)|Dyfed]] announced that he had been killed in action six weeks earlier. The winner's chair was then draped in a black sheet, and was thus delivered to the parents of Hedd Wyn. That year's eisteddfod is now referred to in the [[Welsh language]] as "''Eisteddfod y Gadair Ddu''" ("The Eisteddfod of the Black Chair").
The chair from that ceremony, which was made by a Belgian carpenter, Eugeen Vanfleteren (1880–1950), who had fled to Britain when Belgium was invaded and had settled in Birkenhead,<ref>{{cite book|last=Dehandschutter|first= Lieven|year=2001|title= Hedd Wyn. A Welsh tragedy in Flanders|publisher= Vormingscentrum Lodewijk Dosfel (Gent, Flanders, Belgium|page= 47|isbn=}}</ref> is on display at Yr Ysgwrn, the poet's former home.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-north-west-wales-20857039 |title=BBC News – Wales honours: Libyan Mahdi Jibani MBE for medical and interfaith work |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2012-12-29 |accessdate=2014-05-19}}</ref>
Winning the "double" of bardic chair and [[Crowning of the Bard|crown]] at the same eisteddfod is a feat that has only been performed a handful of times in the history of the eisteddfod. [[Alan Llwyd]] and [[Donald Evans (Welsh poet)|Donald Evans]] have each performed the double twice.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.llgc.org.uk/blog/?p=6837|title= The Chairing of the Bard.|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= National Library of Wales|access-date= 6 April 2016|quote=}}</ref>
The first woman to win the Chair at the National Eisteddfod was [[Mererid Hopwood]] in 2001; she went on to win the crown at a later eisteddfod.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.museumwales.ac.uk/957/|title= Some facts and figures regarding Gorsedd ceremonies|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= National Museum Wales|access-date= 6 April 2016|quote=}}</ref> {{clear}}

'''Common law offences''' are [[crime]]s under [[English criminal law]] and the related criminal law of other [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] countries. They are offences under the [[Common law#History|common law]], developed entirely by the [[law courts]], and therefore have no specific bases in [[statute]].
==Australia== Under the [[criminal law of Australia]] the [[Criminal Code Act 1995]] (Cth) abolished all common law offences at the federal level.<ref name="aph">[http://www.aph.gov.au/library/intguide/law/crimlaw.htm#history History of Australian Criminal Law], Parliament of Australia Library {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330101954/http://www.aph.gov.au/library/intguide/law/crimlaw.htm#history |date=March 30, 2010 }}</ref> The [[Australian Capital Territory]], the [[Northern Territory]], [[Queensland]], [[Tasmania]] and [[Western Australia]] have also abolished common law offences, but they still apply in [[New South Wales]], [[South Australia]] and [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. Although some common law offences still exist in New South Wales, many common law offences- for example nightwalking, riot, rout, affray, keeping of bawdy houses, champerty and maintainence, eavesdropping and being a common scold- have been abolished in that State.
==Canada== In [[Canada]] the consolidation of criminal law in the [[Criminal Code (Canada)|Criminal Code]], enacted in 1953, involved the abolition of all common law offences except [[contempt of court]] (preserved by section 9 of the Code).
==England and Wales== In [[England and Wales]], the [[Law Commission (England and Wales)|Law Commission]]'s programme of codification of the criminal law included the aim of abolishing all the remaining common law offences and replacing them, where appropriate, with offences precisely defined by statute.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lawcom.gov.uk/project/legislating-the-criminal-code/|title=Legislating the Criminal Code - Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.gov.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lawcom.gov.uk/project/criminal-law-a-criminal-code/|title=Criminal Law: A Criminal Code - Law Commission|website=www.lawcom.gov.uk}}</ref> Common law offences were seen as unacceptably vague and open to development by the courts in ways that might offend the principle of certainty. However, neither the Law Commission nor the [[UK Parliament]] have completed the necessary revisions of the law, so common law offences still exist. In [[English law|England and Wales]] common law offences are punishable by unlimited fines and unlimited imprisonment.
Extant common law offences are listed at {{slink|English criminal law|Common law offences}}, and those that have been abolished or redefined as statutory offences are listed at {{slink|History of English criminal law|Common law offences}}.
===List of offences under the common law of England=== {{see also|Category:Common law offences in England and Wales}} This list includes offences that have been abolished or codified in one or more or all jurisdictions:
*[[Murder]] *[[Manslaughter]] *[[Mayhem (crime)|Mayhem]] *[[Common assault]] aka [[assault]] *[[Battery (crime)|Battery]] *[[Assault|Assault with intent to rob]] *[[Assault|Assault with intent to rape]] *[[Kidnapping]] / [[Abduction (disambiguation)|abduction]] *[[Rape]] *[[Buggery]] *[[Arson]] *[[Larceny]] *[[Robbery]] *[[Burglary]] *[[Trespass]] *[[Extortion]] *[[Concealment of treasure trove]] *[[Cheating (law)|Cheating]] *[[Forgery]] *[[High treason]] *[[Petty treason]] *[[Misprision of treason]] (disputed - alleged to be statutory) *[[Misprision of felony]] (disputed - alleged not to exist) *[[Compounding treason]] *[[Sedition]] *[[Seditious libel]] *[[Contempt of the sovereign]] *[[Espionage]] *[[Contempt of court]] a.k.a. [[criminal contempt]], [[contumacy]] *[[Compounding a felony]] *[[False evidence|Fabrication of false evidence]] *[[Escape from lawful custody]] *[[Breach of prison]]/[[breaking prison]] *Rescue/[[rescuing a prisoner in custody]] *[[Harboring a fugitive]] or felon *[[Effecting a public mischief]] (disputed - held to no longer exist) *[[Malicious mischief]] *[[Riot]] *[[Mobbing]] *[[Piracy]] *[[Rout (crime)|Rout]] *[[Affray]] *[[Unlawful assembly]] *[[Breach of the peace]] *[[Defamatory libel]] *(Causing a) [[public nuisance]] *[[Obscene libel]] *[[Blasphemy]] *[[Blasphemous libel]] *[[Incitement]] *[[Provocation (legal)|Challenging to fight]] *[[Champerty and maintenance|Maintenance]] *[[Champerty]] *[[Embracery]] *[[Eavesdropping]] *[[Barratry (common law)|Barratry]], inciting litigation for profit *Being a [[common scold]] *Nightwalking (so as to cause alarm) *[[Outraging public decency]] *[[Forcible entry]] *[[Forcible detainer]] *[[Attempt]] *[[Conspiracy (crime)|Conspiracy]] *[[Accessory (legal term)|Accessory]] *[[Bribery|Offering or paying a bribe]] *[[Inebriation]], [[public intoxication]], [[posing a danger to others]] *Running a [[disorderly house]] * [[Administration of drugs with intent to enable or assist the commission of a crime]] *[[Housebreaking with intent to steal]] *[[Theft]] *[[Use of threats with intent to extort money or property]] *[[Wilful fireraising]] and culpable and [[reckless fireraising]]
See also [[criminal libel]]
====High crimes and misdemeanours====
*[[Misconduct in public office]] *[[Perjury|Perjury of oath]] *[[Abuse of authority]] *[[Failure to appear]]: subpoena, militia call-up, jury notice *[[Command responsibility|Failure to supervise]] *[[Misappropriation|Misappropriation of funds]] *[[Bribery|Acceptance of a bribe]] *[[Dereliction of duty]], Refusal to execute public office *[[Conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman|Conduct unbecoming]] *[[Desertion]], Away without leave *[[Insubordination]], Failure to obey a lawful order *[[Obstruction of justice]], [[perverting the course of justice]], defeating the ends of justice, obstructing the administration of justice *[[False imprisonment]] *[[Dereliction of duty|Permitting an escape]]
See also [[Uniform Code of Military Justice]] for codification of what had been common law crimes.
==New Zealand== In [[New Zealand]] all common law offences were abolished under the [[Crimes Act 1961]], with the exception of [[contempt of court]] and of offences tried by [[court martial|courts martial]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1961/0043/latest/DLM328048.html|title=Crimes Act 1961 No 43 (as at 28 September 2017), Public Act 9 Offences not to be punishable except under New Zealand Acts – New Zealand Legislation|website=www.legislation.govt.nz}}</ref>
==United States== The notion that common law offenses could be enforced in federal courts was found to be unconstitutional by the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] in ''[[United States v. Hudson and Goodwin]]'', 11 U.S. 32 (1812). Some have argued that they are inconsistent with the prohibition of [[ex post facto]] laws.<ref>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/19155586/Common-Law-Crimes-Are-Unconstitutional-as-Ex-Post-Fact-Laws Common Law Crimes Are Unconstitutional as Ex Post Facto Laws], Anthony J. Fejfar (2009)</ref>
At the state level, the situation varies. Some states, such as [[New Jersey]], have abolished common law crimes (see ''[[State v. Palendrano]]''), while others have chosen to continue to recognize them. In some states, the elements of many crimes are defined mostly or entirely by common law, i.e., by prior judicial decisions. For instance, [[Michigan]]'s penal code does not define the crime of [[murder]]: while the penalties for murder are laid out in statute, the actual elements of murder, and their meaning, is entirely set out in case law.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= People v. Aaron|vol= 409|reporter= Mich.|opinion=672 |pinpoint= 713 |court=[[Michigan Supreme Court]] |date=1980 |url= https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=5726386068390560061&hl=en&as_sdt=6&as_vis=1&oi=scholarr |accessdate= 2 April 2018 |quote="In Michigan, murder is not statutorily defined."}}</ref><ref>{{cite act|type=Mich. Comp. Laws |number= § 750.316 |date= 2014 |url= http://www.legislature.mi.gov/(S(nvfvqjm1rwzrroym1e2jcurt))/mileg.aspx?page=GetObject&objectname=mcl-750-316|access-date= 2 April 2018|ref=}}</ref><ref>{{cite act|type=Mich. Comp. Laws |number= § 750.317 |date= 2014 |url= http://www.legislature.mi.gov/(S(nvfvqjm1rwzrroym1e2jcurt))/mileg.aspx?page=GetObject&objectname=mcl-750-317|accessdate= 2 April 2018|ref=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Nullum crimen, nulla poena sine praevia lege poenali]]

==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040121192433/http://www.freebeagles.org/caselaw/CL_frontpage.html CASE LAW on free B.E.A.G.L.E.S. legal resource centre]
