page.title: Concerns and controversies at the 2010 Winter Olympics

revision.comment: Rescuing 6 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:Zyxw|Zyxw]])
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{2010 Winter Olympics}} A number of '''concerns and controversies at the [[2010 Winter Olympics]]''' in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada, surfaced before and during the Games, and which received media coverage.
== Safety ==
=== Death of Georgian athlete Nodar Kumaritashvili === {{Main|Nodar Kumaritashvili}}
Hours before the opening ceremony, [[Nodar Kumaritashvili]] of Georgia was killed during a training run for the [[luge]] after he was thrown from his sled and struck a steel pillar at high speed, near the end of the course.<ref name="bbc-crash"/> The [[International Luge Federation]] called an emergency meeting after the accident, and all other training runs were cancelled for the day.<ref name="bbc-crash">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/olympic_games/vancouver_2010/8513595.stm|title=Olympic luger Nodar Kumaritashvili dies after crash|date=February 12, 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=February 12, 2010}}</ref>
[[Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games|Vancouver Olympics Organizing Committee]] (VANOC) was criticized after members of the media assumed that VANOC was the governing body that conducted a prompt 12-hour investigation into the luger's death, which put the blame on the luger. In fact, it was the [[International Luge Federation]] (ILF) which conducted the investigation. The ILF has stated that it will investigate the crash and issue a report around the end of March 2010.<ref>{{cite news|last=Metreveli|first=Irakli|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/oly2010lugegeokumaritashvilifuneral/print|title=Track controversy hangs over Georgian luger's funeral|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=February 20, 2010}}{{dead link|date=June 2015}}</ref>
Furthermore, the [[Whistler Sliding Centre]], which has recorded some of the fastest speeds in luge history, was the site of several non-fatal accidents during training runs leading up to the start of the games.<ref name="bbc-crash"/> For more than a year prior to the Olympics, luge competitors had complained that the track was too fast and the turns were too dangerous. Athletes had nicknamed turn 13 the "50-50" turn for their chances of getting through it without crashing. Kumaritashvili was killed on turn 16, the last turn of the course.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robertson|first=Linda|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/columnists/linda-robertson/story/1478096.html|title=At Winter Olympics, grief before Opening Ceremonies|newspaper=[[Miami Herald]]|date=February 19, 2010}}{{dead link|date=June 2015}}</ref>
As a result, the height of the wall Kumaritashvili surmounted was increased, with added wooden panels and padding. Officials also ordered changes to the layout of the final turn of the Whistler luge track, making it slower and safer, and moved the men's and women's luge starts down the track.<ref name="luge track">{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2010/luge/news/story?id=4911258|title=Officials insist track is safe|date=February 13, 2010|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=February 14, 2010}}</ref>
Kumaritashvili's teammate, [[Levan Gureshidze]], did not race. He was on the official start list for the first run but withdrew, telling other racers he could not go on.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2010/luge/news/story?id=4911258 |title=Olympians slide with heavy hearts |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=February 14, 2010}}</ref> He instead flew back to Georgia to mourn the loss of his fallen teammate.<ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2010/luge/news/story?id=4920689 Luger Nodar Kumaritashvili's body returns to hometown in Georgia - ESPN<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
After the starting gates were changed, competitors have complained that the junior starting position enters the main track with a turn that is too tight, causing sledders problems at the beginning of their runs.<ref name=Slot/> Some have also complained that slowing the course has decreased the challenge and forced them to adjust their strategy.{{Who|date=March 2010}}
Eleven months before the death of Kumaritashvili, [[Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games|VANOC]] chief executive officer John Furlong started to be concerned that an athlete could get "badly injured or even worse" on the luge track.<ref name="Globe1">{{Cite news|title=VANOC feared injury 'or worse' year before luger's fatal crash|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/british-columbia/vanoc-feared-injury-or-worse-year-before-lugers-fatal-crash/article1896694/|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=February 6, 2011|accessdate=February 7, 2011|location=Toronto|first1=Rod|last1=Mickleburgh|first2=Jeff|last2=Blair}}</ref><ref name="CBC1">{{Cite news|title=Fatal luge track worried VANOC: CBC probe |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2011/02/06/vanoc-luge-track406.html |publisher=CBC News |date=February 6, 2011 |accessdate=February 7, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208124354/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2011/02/06/vanoc-luge-track406.html |archivedate=February 8, 2011 }}</ref> Josef Fendt, who is the President of the [[International Luge Federation]], stated in a letter to the designer of the luge track that luge track was recording "historic sled speeds" that the speeds were nearly 20 kilometres an hour faster than the track designer had anticipated.<ref name="Globe1"/> John Furlong received a copy of the letter and asked for the situation to be looked at by the "legal guys".<ref name="Globe1"/> Svein Romstad, general secretary of the [[International Luge Federation]], stated that the [[International Luge Federation]] "would have sought major changes to the Whistler track if it had known ahead of time that speeds would be so much higher than calculated."<ref name="Globe1"/> A memo dated January 30, 2006 stated that, in March 2005, the [[International Luge Federation]] wanted major changes to six curves on the luge track including curves 15 and 16, where Kumaritashvili's problem began.<ref name="CBC1"/> Kumaritashvili's father became angry after reports showed that VANOC didn't act on their own concerns about the luge track's safety.<ref name="TorontoStar1">{{Cite news|title=Luger's father angry VANOC didn't act on track dangers|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/olympics/article/934543--luger-s-father-angry-vanoc-didn-t-act-on-track-dangers?bn=1|publisher=Toronto Star|date=February 7, 2011|accessdate=February 7, 2011|first=Randy|last=Kman}}</ref> The family of Kumaritashvili received an insurance payout worth $150,000 from the VANOC.<ref name="TorontoStar1"/>
VANOC broke some rules in regards to the luging and bobsleigh track. [[International Luge Federation]] states that "the length for a luge track must not exceed {{convert|1350|m|feet}}."<ref name="CBC2">{{Cite news|title=Deadly luge track may have stretched the rules |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2011/02/10/f-luge-death-notebook.html |publisher=CBC News |date=February 10, 2011 |accessdate=February 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110214095642/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2011/02/10/f-luge-death-notebook.html |archivedate=February 14, 2011 }}</ref> [[G-force]] was critical in the accident that killed Kumaritashvili.<ref name="CBC2"/> The rules of the [[Fédération Internationale de Bobsleigh et de Tobogganing|International Bobsleigh and Tobogganing Federation]] states that a g-force of 5 is the limit for the track.<ref name="CBC2"/> A g-force of 5.02 is possible for male lugers on the track in [[Whistler, British Columbia|Whistler]].<ref name="CBC2"/> The rules of the International Bobsleigh and Tobogganing Federation also states that "to prevent the deterioration of the ice during warm, sunny periods, the finish straight should be shaded or covered."<ref name="CBC2"/> Part of what was to be considered in the shading of the finish straight was the safety of the athlete.<ref name="CBC2"/> The final straight was where the accident took place.<ref name="CBC2"/> Since the investigation and currently, sliders no longer start at the upper start area, they start {{convert|190|m}} downhill at the lower start: C1.
The [[President of Georgia]], [[Mikheil Saakashvili]], thanked the hosts for the way that they handled Kumaritashvili's death which included a moment of silence and a tribute at the opening ceremony.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/winter-olympics/7293583/Winter-Olympics-2010-Vancouver-so-passionate-to-embrace-Games-says-Seb-Coe.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Sebastian | last1=Coe | title=Winter Olympics 2010: Vancouver so passionate to embrace Games, says Seb Coe | date=February 23, 2010}}</ref>
=== Other safety concerns ===
Given Kumaritshvili's death on the 12th, other safety issues on speed for other events were raised at these games, most notably at the Sliding Centre.<ref name=yhoo022210>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/olympics/news;_ylt=AqjD6LtIXohlZ09PrTIJXcSNsbV_?slug=ap-weighingtherisk&prov=ap&type=lgns&print=1 |title=Critical safety reviews lie ahead after Olympics |date=February 21, 2010 |first1=David |last1=Crary |first2=Stephen |last2=Wilson |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Yahoo! Sports |accessdate=February 22, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Another noted injury took place in the [[Alpine skiing at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Women's downhill|women's downhill]]. The course was labelled as extremely difficult for skiers and most training runs were cancelled due to weather conditions. This resulted in several accidents during the competition event where [[Sweden at the 2010 Winter Olympics|Sweden]]'s [[Anja Pärson]] was badly bruised following a jump prior to the finish line of the event on February 17.<ref name=yhoo022210 />
In [[Cross-country skiing at the 2010 Winter Olympics|cross-country skiing]], Slovenian skier [[Petra Majdič]] was severely injured after a fall during a practice run on the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Women's sprint|sprint track]]. The fall led to Majdič sliding off the course and falling down a rocky slope. Despite having broken ribs and a collapsed lung, Majdič completed the women's sprint event and took the bronze medal. Slovenia filed a protest with the IOC about the safety of the course, but it was dismissed.<ref name=nbc030110>{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/news-features/news/newsid=432093.html |title=Majdic won bronze with collapsed lung |date=February 21, 2010 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=NBCOlympics |accessdate=March 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100310002944/http://www.nbcolympics.com/news-features/news/newsid%3D432093.html |archivedate=March 10, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== Safety at LiveCity Vancouver ===
Dozens were injured and sent to hospital when a barricade erected at LiveCity Yaletown collapsed. Canadian rock band [[Alexisonfire]] played a free concert at LiveCity [[Yaletown]] on Tuesday, February 16. Ten seconds into the band's first song, the crowd of hundreds surged forward, which caused a section of the barricade to collapse, sending dozens to the ground. The band stopped playing immediately, and asked the crowd to step back. While Vancouver Police and on-site medical team controlled the situation, the crowd was informed that the show was cancelled, and they dispersed quickly and co-operatively.<ref name=Safety>{{cite news |last=Woo |first=Andrea |url=https://vancouversun.com/opinion/More+than+injured+crowd+topples+fence+Yaletown+LiveCity/2573504/story.html |title=Twenty people injured as crowd topples fence at Yaletown LiveCity |newspaper=[[Vancouver Sun]] |date=February 17, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100221060322/http://www.vancouversun.com/opinion/More%2Bthan%2Binjured%2Bcrowd%2Btopples%2Bfence%2BYaletown%2BLiveCity/2573504/story.html |archivedate=February 21, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Reports indicate at least 20 people were injured with 10 being taken to hospital. On February 17 the band issued the following statement: "We are sincerely sorry that people were injured. We want to thank the security team, paramedics and police for their quick reaction. We especially want to thank our fans for cooperating and not making a bad situation worse." A representative for LiveCity Vancouver added "When the incident occurred, everyone acted quickly, professionally, and took appropriate action. The security and on-site emergency medical response teams provided immediate assistance and care, the band kept people calm, and the crowd dispersed safely."<ref name=Safety/>
== Bilingualism == {{See also|2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony}}
The opening ceremony was criticized for a perceived lack of appropriate representation of French-speaking Canadians, in spite of Canada's status as a bilingual country. One who raised objections was the Secretary General of [[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie|La Francophonie]], [[Abdou Diouf]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vivezvancouver.radio-canada.ca/vivezvancouver/CultureSociete/2010/02/12/004-francais_place.shtml|title=Déception chez les observateurs|date=February 12, 2010 |publisher=Radio-Canada|accessdate =February 12, 2010}}</ref> Quebec Premier [[Jean Charest]] said the ceremony failed to respect and reflect the Francophone community in Canada.<ref name="moore">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/02/14/olympics-french-charest-moore.html |title=Olympics need more French: heritage minister |date=February 14, 2010 |publisher=CBC |accessdate=February 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216151710/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/02/14/olympics-french-charest-moore.html |archivedate=February 16, 2010 }}</ref> In an interview with [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]], the [[Minister of Canadian Heritage]], [[James Moore (Canadian politician)|James Moore]], was "disappointed" by the low representation of French during the ceremony.<ref name="moore"/><ref name=OC15Feb2010>{{cite news|newspaper=The Ottawa Citizen|title=Heritage minister 'disappointed' by lack of French|first1=Mike|last1=Barber|first2=Jeff|last2=Lee|date=February 15, 2010|page=A5}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fr.canoe.ca/infos/quebeccanada/archives/2010/02/20100214-173645.html|title=Comme la neige, le français se fait rare à Vancouver|date=February 14, 2010 |publisher=TVA|accessdate =February 14, 2010}}</ref> Canadian Member of Parliament [[Richard Nadeau]] of the [[Bloc Québécois]] sees rather a lack of political will to promote [[Official bilingualism in Canada|Canadian bilingualism]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberpresse.ca/le-droit/dossiers/vancouver-2010/201002/14/01-949646-un-manque-de-volonte-deplore-le-depute-richard-nadeau.php|title=Un manque de volonté, déplore le député Richard Nadeau|date=February 14, 2010 |publisher=TVA|accessdate =February 14, 2010}}</ref> Among the 25,000 volunteers, only 15% of them speak French.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberpresse.ca/sports/vancouver-2010/201002/14/01-949640-seuls-15-des-25000-benevoles-parlent-le-francais.php|title=Seuls 15% des 25 000 bénévoles parlent le français|date=February 14, 2010 |publisher=TVA|accessdate =February 14, 2010}}</ref> The [[Office of the Commissioner of Official Languages|Commissioner of the Official Languages]], [[Graham Fraser]], was very disappointed by the lack of presence of French. He also said, "I had the impression of watching a show designed and produced in English with a French song. Even l'''Hymne du Nord'' from the poet [[François-Xavier Garneau]] has been translated into English to be read by the actor [[Donald Sutherland]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberpresse.ca/sports/vancouver-2010/201002/14/01-949639-le-francais-aussi-rare-que-la-neige-a-vancouver.php|title=Le français aussi rare que la neige à Vancouver|date=February 15, 2010 |publisher=cyberpresse|accessdate =December 14, 2010}}</ref>
VANOC, however, defended the case and said that they had made "a very deliberate focus and effort to ensure a strong celebration of Quebec culture and language."<ref>{{cite news|title=VANOC defends French content of opening ceremony|date=February 15, 2010|first=Rod|last=Mickleburgh|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|page=A6}}</ref> They also said that there was a significant amount of French in the opening ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|title=Not everyone happy with amount of French content at kickoff|date=February 15, 2010|first=Jeff|last=Lee|newspaper=The Vancouver Sun|page=A2}}</ref> [[David Atkins]], the artistic director of the opening ceremonies, said that the ceremonies did celebrate francophone Canada.<ref name=French>{{cite news|title=Political bigwigs and languages commissioner decry lack of French at Games|date=February 14, 2010|first=Dene|last=Moore|agency=Canadian Press}}</ref> Some examples of the French include the speeches, the [[Olympic Hymn]], and the officials' oath. [[John Furlong (Canadian)|John Furlong]], VANOC CEO, [[Presidents of the International Olympic Committee|IOC President]] [[Jacques Rogge]], and [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]] [[Michaëlle Jean]] all addressed the crowd in English and French.<ref name=French/> [[Measha Brueggergosman]] performed the English version of the Olympic Hymn, but [[Dave Pierce]], the music director for the games, had his associate, Donovan Seidle, compose and arrange it to have some of the stanzas performed in French.<ref>{{cite AV media|title=Sounds of Vancouver 2010: Opening Ceremony Commemorative Album|medium=CD|date=2010}}</ref> [[Michel Verrault]], a speed-skating official, took the [[Olympic oath|officials' oath]] in French.
In his official report on the 2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony, Graham Fraser identified two causes for the lack of french in it. The first was lack of understanding. The commissioner said that "it was apparent that, in several areas, the official language requirements in the multi-party agreement signed by the organizing committee and [[Canadian Heritage]] were rather vague and unclear". He also stated the secrecy traditionally given to the opening ceremony prevented the commissioner from making sure that Canada's linguistic duality was well-showcased in the show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ici.radio-canada.ca/nouvelle/497219/jo-vancouver-rapport-graham-fraser|title=Graham Fraser remet son rapport final|last=Radio-Canada|date=|website=Radio-Canada.ca|language=fr-ca|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> In order to prevent such mistake for future major events held in Canada, such as the [[2015 Pan American Games|2015 Panamerican Games]], "official language requirements must be specific and clear to ensure that organizing committees grasp the importance of linguistic duality, understand their official languages obligations and plan adequately." In early 2011, the [[Office of the Commissioner of Official Languages]] published guide in early 2011 based on the lessons learned at the Vancouver Games to help federal institutions and organizing committees of future large-scale sporting events to better understand, plan, implement, and monitor their activities toward the full respect and inclusion of English and French.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.officiallanguages.gc.ca/en/news/releases/2010/2010-12-14|title=Commissioner looks forward after linguistic shortfalls of the 2010 Olympic Games|date=|website=www.officiallanguages.gc.ca|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref>
In February 2011, one year following the Vancouver games, [[John Furlong (sports administrator)|Furlong]] discussed the language controversy in the Olympics in his book ''Patriot Hearts: Inside the Olympics that Changed a Country''. Furlong said he had received praise from Fraser before the opening ceremony because of the large amount of bilinguals in his staff. He added that he had attempted to have the Quebec Anthem ''[[Mon Pays]]'' sang at the ceremony as well, but were shot down by the [[Gilles Vigneault|song's author]]. Furlong defended his refusal to apologise for the perceived lack of french in the opening ceremony. He alleged that, when discussing the place of French at the Olympics, "Mr. Fraser pointed fingers from a distance but rarely pitched in with ideas or support."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/books-and-media/vancouver-olympic-ceo-john-furlongs-book-recalls-language-controversy/article565307/|title=Vancouver Olympic CEO John Furlong's book recalls language controversy|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> Fraser answered these criticism, saying that his office had given him precise indications and ideas to promote linguistic duality during the games, which were implemented. He said that, overall, the services in the Games were provided in both official languages, and that the absence of french was mostly in the cultural program, and this was the only part he took issue with.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/furlongs-explanation-for-lack-of-french-at-2010-games-criticized/article565652/|title=Furlong's explanation for lack of French at 2010 Games criticized|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> Following the release of Furlong's book on the 2010 Games, [[La Presse (Canadian newspaper)|La Presse]] editor André Pratte wrote a severe opinion piece on the lack of French in the opening ceremony, noting that "just trying is not good enough."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/opinion/editorialopinion/article/937665--no-medal-for-bilingualism|title=No medal for bilingualism - thestar.com|last=Pratte|first=André|date=February 12, 2011|work=[[Toronto Star]]|publisher=Toronto Star|accessdate=February 14, 2011}}</ref>
== H1N1 pandemic == {{See also|2009 flu pandemic|2009 flu pandemic in Canada}}
There have been concerns that the [[H1N1 virus]] could spread among spectators, staff and athletes during the games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvbc.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20090718/BC_olympic_virus_090718/20090718/?hub=BritishColumbiaHome |title=CTV British Columbia- Officials focus on H1N1 plan ahead of Olympics – CTV News, Shows and Sports – Canadian Television |publisher=Ctvbc.ctv.ca |date= |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/HEALTH/01/13/olympics.flu.preps/ | work=CNN | title=Canada's Olympic-sized plan to fight H1N1 - CNN.com | accessdate=April 30, 2010 | date=January 18, 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ctvolympics.ca/health/news/newsid=20922.html Health and Wellness News- 2010 Winter Olympics - CTV Olympics<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309233811/http://www.ctvolympics.ca/health/news/newsid%3D20922.html |date=March 9, 2010 }}</ref> Organizers were stockpiling vaccine and placed a high priority on vaccinating all volunteers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/other_news/1216134522.html |title=Vancouver 2010 To Vaccinate Against H1N1 |publisher=GamesBids.com |date= |accessdate=January 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320051852/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/other_news/1216134522.html |archivedate=March 20, 2012 }}</ref> While each country was responsible for the vaccination of its own athletic delegation, Vancouver health officials and the [[International Olympic Committee]] strongly recommended all athletes, spectators and other visitors be vaccinated.<ref>{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Daniels|url=http://www.king5.com/health/Vancouver-2010---Preparing-for-H1N1-69243187.html|title=Vancouver 2010 – Preparing for H1N1|publisher=King5.com|date=November 4, 2009|accessdate=January 10, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110000540/http://www.king5.com/health/Vancouver-2010---Preparing-for-H1N1-69243187.html#|archive-date=January 10, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sports-city.org/news_details.php?news_id=9850&idCategory=40 |title=2010 athletes, spectators urged to get H1N1 shots |publisher=Sports-city.org |date=October 29, 2009 |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref> Some Olympic Committees required their delegations to be vaccinated against the [[2009 flu pandemic|H1N1 flu]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory?id=8956791 |title=Italy Plans Swine Flu Vaccinations for Vancouver – ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=October 30, 2009 |accessdate=January 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kvOK1uLP?url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory?id=8956791 |archivedate=October 31, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In light of concerns, local British Columbia health officials vaccinated participants and spectators for free during the duration of the games.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2010/02/bc-offering-h1n1-shots-to-olympic-athletes.html The Rundown News Blog | Olympic Athletes, Fans Offered H1N1 Vaccination by Host B.C. | Online NewsHour | PBS<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gdPrYeGPRWKW3p4G85TGz4LAJM4g |accessdate=February 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nL00SXNp?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gdPrYeGPRWKW3p4G85TGz4LAJM4g |archivedate=February 6, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
== Women's ski jumping ==
The IOC voted in 2006 not to include women's ski jumping in the 2010 Games on the grounds that the sport was not yet developed enough and did not meet basic criteria for inclusion. The members of the Canadian Women Ski Jumping Team filed a grievance with the Canadian Human Rights Board citing gender discrimination.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/2008-01-18-2335162792_x.htm |title=Groups to press IOC to allow women's ski jumping in 2010 Olympics|date=January 18, 2008|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=August 26, 2008}}</ref>
According to lobby group Women's Ski Jumping USA, a group composed of "some of the top women ski jumpers", filed a Statement of Claim with the Supreme Court of British Columbia suing the Vancouver Olympic Organizing Committee for excluding women ski jumpers from the Vancouver games claiming that their rights were violated according to the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Women ski jumpers suing for 2010 Olympic spot |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/amateur/story/2008/05/21/ski-jump-lawsuit.html |publisher=[[CBC Sports]] |date=March 23, 2008 |accessdate=January 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531002734/http://www.cbc.ca/sports/amateur/story/2008/05/21/ski-jump-lawsuit.html |archivedate=May 31, 2008 }}</ref> However, on June 10, 2009, the Supreme Court ruled against the group, stating that though the women were being discriminated against,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctvolympics.ca/ski-jumping/news/newsid=12739.html#no+female+flight+2010?cid=rssctv |title=CTV Olympics – No female flight in 2010: B.C. court rejects ski jump bid |publisher=Ctvolympics.ca |date=July 10, 2009 |accessdate=January 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109131020/http://www.ctvolympics.ca/ski-jumping/news/newsid%3D12739.html#no+female+flight+2010?cid=rssctv |archivedate=January 9, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> the issue is an International Olympic Committee responsibility, and thus is not governed by the Charter, and finally, the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms did not apply to VANOC, with the term, "In other words, VANOC is not under a duty to distribute equally what it has no power to provide."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/07/10/bc-olympic-women-ski-jump-decision.html |title=CBC – NFemale ski jumpers lose Olympic battle |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=July 10, 2009 |accessdate=January 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090714160644/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/07/10/bc-olympic-women-ski-jump-decision.html |archivedate=July 14, 2009 }}</ref>
== Athletes' Village ==
[[File:Whistlerolyvillage.PNG|thumb|[[Whistler Olympic Village|Whistler Athletes' Village]] (more athletes stayed there than at the village in Vancouver)]]
The [[2010 Olympic Village|athletes' village]] located at Southeast False Creek was originally planned to be a model sustainable community, with state-of-the-art energy efficiency provisions, and a mix of market and [[Public housing|social housing]], at one third market, one third social housing and one third subsidized middle income housing. The city of Vancouver would break even through the sale of market housing. However, a new city council in 2005 dropped the provisions for subsidized middle income housing and then sold the lands to a private developer for [[Canadian dollar|C$]]193 million.<ref>Kear, M. (2007) "Spaces of transition—spaces of tomorrow: making a sustainable future in Southeast False Creek", in: ''Vancouver Cities''; Vol. 24, No. 4, pp. 324–334</ref> Further controversy erupted when the private developer and its associated investment company backed out of the project, forcing the city of Vancouver to bear the liability, which resulted in the resignation of a city planner in protest and saw the city seek special legislation making changes to its charter to allow it to borrow money to finance completion of the project.<ref name="Mackin">{{cite web|last=Mackin |first=Bob |url=https://thetyee.ca/Blogs/TheHook/Olympics2010/2009/06/19/OlympicVillageReports/ |title=''Vancouver releases secret Olympic Village documents'', Bob Mackin, ''The Tyee'', June 19, 2009 |publisher=Thetyee.ca |date=June 19, 2009 |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref><ref name="bctrialofbasi-virk.blogspot.com">[http://bctrialofbasi-virk.blogspot.com/search?q=fortress Speech by [[Corky Evans]] in the BC Legislature, Thursday, January 29, 2009, from BC [[Hansard]], Legislature Raids/Basi-Virk Trial webpage]</ref>
Leading up to the Olympics, the [[International Olympic Committee]] had ordered the removal of a two-story high Australian [[Boxing Kangaroo]] flag which had been draped over a balcony in the athletes' village. The IOC ordered the flag to be taken down because they believed the image to be too commercial as it is a registered trademark (albeit of the Australian Olympic Committee).<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/decision-on-boxing-kangaroo-ridiculous/story-e6frfku0-1225826968149 Decision on boxing kangaroo 'ridiculous'] – news.com.au, February 5, 2010</ref> The order for removal was later withdrawn after IOC president [[Jacques Rogge]] met with AOC president [[John Coates (sports administrator)|John Coates]].<ref name=decision2>[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/breaking-news/boxing-kangaroo-to-fly-at-aussie-village/story-e6freuyi-1225827883050 Boxing kangaroo to fly at Aussie village] – ''The Daily Telegraph'', February 8, 2010</ref>
== Opening ceremonies content ==
On August 22, 2008, ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' reported that the [[Premiership of Stephen Harper|government]] of [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] mandated that the content of the [[2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremonies]] reflect its agenda as a condition of its contribution of [[Canadian dollar|C$]]20 million to fund the event. This was widely criticized as government interference with the arts and exercising ideological control. However, VANOC vice-president of communications Renée Smith-Valade said the government was not bringing politics into the 2010 games and did not have veto power over any part of the Olympic ceremonies.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ottawa aims to put its stamp on 2010 Games: Vancouver opening ceremony must help Harper government 'achieve its domestic and international branding goals,' memo says |date=August 22, 2008 |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |last=Matas |first=Robert |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/article705918.ece |accessdate=August 22, 2008 |location=Toronto |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090722061734/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/article705918.ece |archivedate=July 22, 2009 }}</ref>
== Security violation ==
A mentally ill man from British Columbia was able to use a homemade all-access pass at the opening ceremonies to clear several layers of security at BC Place Stadium and get close to [[Vice President of the United States|U.S. Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]], who authorities say the man had an infatuation with. Before he could reach Biden, however, he was stopped by two plainclothes Mounties, who escorted him away. The man will not face charges, but has been committed to a psychiatric facility. The [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) said it has not implemented any change in security at the Olympics following the breach.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctvolympics.ca/news-centre/newsid=44595.html#man+infatuated+with+u+s+vp+breaches+2010+security?cid=rssctv |title=Man infatuated with U.S. VP breaches security |publisher=CTVOlympics.ca |accessdate=February 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220073757/http://www.ctvolympics.ca/news-centre/newsid%3D44595.html#man+infatuated+with+u+s+vp+breaches+2010+security?cid=rssctv |archivedate=February 20, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
== Cooptation of lines from national anthem ==
VANOC used lines from the [[O Canada|Canadian national anthem]] to serve as the official slogans for the games ("with glowing hearts" in English and "des plus brilliants exploits" in French) and trademarked their use. However, VANOC stated it would only challenge usage of the lines in the case of [[ambush marketing]], where an attempt is made to "create a specific, unauthorized commercial association with the 2010 Winter Games".<ref name=VANOCProtect/> The anthem itself is in the [[public domain]].<ref name=VANOCProtect>{{cite web | url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/en/about-vanoc/the-vancouver-2010-brand/protecting-the-brand/-/32798/1i3nwix/index.html | title = Protecting the Brand | accessdate = November 22, 2008 | work = Vancouver 2010 | publisher = Vanoc | location = Vancouver, British Columbia }}</ref><ref name="olympicmotto">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2008/09/25/bc-vancouver-olympics-trademark-o-canada.html |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=January 7, 2009 |title=Olympic mottoes borrow lines from O Canada |date=January 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106174018/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2008/09/25/bc-vancouver-olympics-trademark-o-canada.html |archivedate=January 6, 2009 }}</ref> <!-- sponsors such as Macdonald's and Visa also coopted lines from the anthem for their advertising campaigns -->
== Trademark enforcement ==
VANOC also began protecting its brand as contractually obligated by the International Olympic Committee and its marketing partners, filing lawsuits against residents attempting to register domain names related to the games, and preventing Vancouver author [[Kari-Lynn Winters]] from portraying the Olympics in a work of fiction.<ref name=ibby>Givens, Cherie (2008). [http://www.ibby.org/index.php?id=870 "Pre-censorship of children’s books: Curtailing the freedom of speech and expression of Canadian authors and illustrators"]. Ibby.org. Retrieved 10-04-09.</ref><ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Forbidden-Fruit-Censorship-Literature-Information/dp/1599424800 ''Forbidden Fruit: censorship of literature and information for young people],'' by Sara McNicol ([[Brown Walker Press]], 2008), pages 61, 63</ref> The VANOC also sued local businesses for using "olympic" in their names, including already-existent and long-established businesses. The [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]] also passed laws granting protection for various terms surrounding the games.<ref name="olympicmotto"/>
== Civil rights and Integrated Security Unit ==
In June 2009, the Olympics Resistance Network accused the Vancouver 2010 Integrated Security Unit's (VISU) Joint Intelligence Group of "abusive and unlawful conduct" after allegedly harassing VANOC opposition activists.<ref>{{cite news |title=Olympics protesters ask 2010 security to stop 'abusive and unlawful conduct' |first=Lora |last=Grindlay |publisher=The Province |date=June 25, 2009 |url=https://theprovince.com/news/Olympics+protestors+2010+security+stop+abusive+unlawful+conduct/1729031/story.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216181406/http://www.theprovince.com/news/Olympics%2Bprotestors%2B2010%2Bsecurity%2Bstop%2Babusive%2Bunlawful%2Bconduct/1729031/story.html |archivedate=February 16, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Concerns over policing methods have also been raised because of the head of Olympic security, RCMP Asst. Commissioner Gary Russell "Bud" Mercer, was part of the RCMP forces that blew up a truck in course of the [[Gustafsen Lake Standoff]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thetyee.ca/News/2009/10/20/GustafsenStandOff/ |title=''Olympics' Top Cop Helped Blow up Truck at Gustafsen Stand-off'', Geoff Dembicki and Bob Mackin, Vancouver 24 Hours, Today, TheTyee.ca. October 19, 2009 |publisher=Thetyee.ca |date= |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref> Mercer was also among the RCMP who pepper-sprayed protests at the 1997 [[APEC]] conference at UBC, personally spraying a [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] cameraman and his camera, and also was part of the "War in the Woods" against [[tree sitting|tree-sit]] protesters in the [[Elaho River|Elaho Valley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thetyee.ca/News/2009/10/22/MercerPepperSpray/ |title=''Mercer Blasted APEC Protesters with Pepper Spray'', Bob Mackin, ''Vancouver 24 hours'' and Geoff Dembicki, ''The Tyee'', October 22, 2009 |publisher=Thetyee.ca |date= |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref>
In October 2009, the [[Legislative Assembly of British Columbia]] through the ''Miscellaneous Statutes Amendment Act, 2009'', gave host municipalities ([[Richmond, British Columbia|Richmond]], [[Vancouver]] and [[Whistler, British Columbia|Whistler]]) the power to enter residences and other private property to seize signs that are deemed to be "anti-Olympic", between February 1 and March 31, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leg.bc.ca/39th1st/3rd_read/gov13-3.htm |title=MISCELLANEOUS STATUTES AMENDMENT ACT, 2009 |publisher=Leg.bc.ca |date= |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref> Another amendment changed the [[Vancouver Charter]] to allow for fines of up to $10,000 and imprisonment for up to 6 months for sign and bylaw violations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bccla.org/pressreleases/09bill13.html |title=BCCLA condemns unlucky B.C. Government Bill 13 |publisher=Bccla.org |date=October 9, 2009 |accessdate=January 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016112039/http://www.bccla.org/pressreleases/09bill13.html |archivedate=October 16, 2009 }}</ref>
Privacy rights advocates, including Chantal Bernier, assistant [[Privacy Commissioner of Canada|federal privacy commissioner]], are concerned about the implementation of 900 [[security cameras]] placed by the RCMP Olympic Integrated Security Unit plus another 100 security cameras placed by the city of Vancouver in the [[Downtown Vancouver|Downtown]] area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvbc.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20100201/bc_cameras_security_100201/20100201?hub=BritishColumbia|title=1,000 security cameras watching Vancouver, Whistler|publisher=[[CTV.ca]]|accessdate=February 1, 2010}}</ref>
== Foreclosure of Whistler resort owner Intrawest ==
Creditors holding $1.4 billion in debt on Intrawest, the owners of the [[Whistler Blackcomb|Whistler Blackcomb Resort]], were reported on January 20, 2010, as being ready to foreclose on the resort as part of the creditor, investment bank [[Lehman Brothers]], attempting to recover debts owed it by major creditors, including [[Fortress Investment Group|Fortress Investments]], the owner of Intrawest and Whistler Blackcomb since 2006. Despite guarantees from VANOC and the Canadian government of $50 million to keep Intrawest afloat during the Games, there were doubts that the Canadian government would be forthcoming. A private source connected to [[Wesley Edens]], owner of Fortress Investments, has said that Edens may exercise his right in that circumstance to prevent the Games from happening at the resort.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kosman |first=Josh |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/intrawest_foreclosure_threat_to_15qRjmzgdwLCkGfNdhdwjI |title=''Intrawest foreclosure a threat to Olympics'', Josh Kosman and Mark deCambre, ''New York Post'', January 20, 2010 |publisher=Nypost.com |date=January 20, 2010 |accessdate=February 7, 2010}}</ref> VANOC sources say this is unlikely to happen since the creditors would have no reason to diminish the value of the resort that would be enhanced by hosting a prestige event, and also because of the short time-frame of the impending Games relative to the length of the legal proceedings of any auction of Fortress' assets.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2010/01/20/sports/sports-us-olympics-vancouver-intrawest.html?_r=1&scp=6&sq=vancouver&st=cse ''Vancouver Downplays Ski Venue Dispute'', Reuters, January 20, 2010, as published in the ''New York Times'']</ref> Fortress is also the company which backed out of the original funding arrangements for the Athletes' Village in Vancouver, and the re-financing of that project by emergency legislation and the involvement of Fortress' subsidiary, Millennium.<ref name="Mackin"/><ref name="bctrialofbasi-virk.blogspot.com"/>
== Failure of ice resurfacers ==
The [[Speed skating at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|men's 500 metres]] speed skating event was delayed for over an hour at the [[Richmond Olympic Oval]] when both [[ice resurfacer]]s experienced mechanical failures and a third ice machine was unable to resurface the ice properly. At least one skater withdrew from the race because of the delay and other racers stated that the delay hurt their race times.<ref>Ford, Bonnie, "[http://sports.espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2010/speedskating/news/story?id=4917326 Davis withdraws after first run]", ''[[ESPN]]'', February 16, 2010.</ref>
Ice resurfacers at the games were supplied by Olympia, an official sponsor of the games. The [[Resurfice Corporation|Olympia Celletwi]] model is the first pollution-free, nickel-cadmium, battery-powered ice resurfacer and was selected as a part of the games "green" efforts. Following the failures, a traditional natural gas powered resurfacer built by [[Ice resurfacer|Zamboni]] was brought in from [[Calgary]]. Organizers stated safety concerns for the decision.<ref name="ice resurfacing">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61F12C20100216?type=sportsNews|title=Speed skating ice woes threaten green sheen|date=February 16, 2010|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=February 16, 2010}}</ref><ref name="business week glitches">{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-02-17/shaun-white-fans-shut-out-as-olympic-glitches-pile-up-update1-.html |title=Shaun White Fans Shut Out as Olympic Glitches Pile Up |date=February 17, 2010 |work=Business Week |accessdate=February 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220224107/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-02-17/shaun-white-fans-shut-out-as-olympic-glitches-pile-up-update1-.html |archivedate=February 20, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/olympics/news?slug=capress-oly_zamboni-161398818&prov=capress&type=lgns |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170103094314/https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/olympics/news/?slug=capress-oly_zamboni-161398818&prov=capress&type=lgns |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 3, 2017 |title=Canadian ice-resurfacer snafu highlights rivalry with U.S. giant Zamboni |publisher=Yahoo Sports, Canada |accessdate=February 18, 2010 }}</ref>
== Ticketing ==
About 28,000 tickets for spectator places along the slopes of a number of outside events were recalled for safety reasons; ticket holders were reimbursed but had difficulty or were not able to gain access to tickets at comparable prices to these events.<ref name=spiegelol>{{cite web| url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/wintersport/0,1518,678465,00.html |author=spiegelonline sport |title=Möge das Wirrwarr gewinnen.|language=German |date=February 18, 2010 |accessdate=February 18, 2010}}</ref> Visitors were also upset by a twenty dollar charge to attend ceremonies to honor medal-winning athletes.<ref name=spiegelol/> Traditionally, these ceremonies had been free of charge.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} Organizers also expressed concern about blocks of VIP tickets going unused leaving conspicuous empty seats at events.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://vancouversun.com/Olympic+tickets+going+unused/2572915/story.html |title=VIP Olympic tickets going unused |date=February 15, 2010 |publisher=Vancouver Sun |accessdate=February 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225091633/http://www.vancouversun.com/Olympic%2Btickets%2Bgoing%2Bunused/2572915/story.html |archivedate=February 25, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In May 2010, VANOC announced that 200 people had to be reimbursed due to alleged fraudulent ticket purchases by a group of Latvians in the province who used compromised credit card information. The cost to VANOC was estimated at $2 million.<ref>{{cite news |title= Latvian ticket scam costs VANOC $2-million |author= Ian Bailey |newspaper= Globe and Mail|date= May 19, 2010|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/british-columbia/latvian-ticket-scam-costs-vanoc-2-million/article1574668/ |location=Toronto}}</ref>
== Officiating errors ==
Observers and participants reported that several starter errors occurred during the February 16 [[Biathlon at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Men's pursuit|men's biathlon pursuit]]. Competitors [[Jeremy Teela]] and [[Jean-Philippe Leguellec]] were started too early, before racers who were seeded higher than them. Teela stated that the early start threw-off his strategy, contributing to his missing two targets in his first two shooting range stops. Teela said, "We have a couple more races this week. Hopefully the organizers figure this problem out and they make the races fair."<ref name=Error>{{cite news|last=Gustus|first=Lauren|agency=[[Gannett News Service]]|url=http://militarytimes.com/news/2010/02/gns_army_teela_olympics_021610/|title=Starter error frustrates biathletes, guardsman|newspaper=[[Military Times]]|date=February 18, 2010}}</ref>
Starter confusion was also present during the [[Biathlon at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Women's pursuit|women's pursuit]] earlier that day. This time both [[Liudmila Kalinchik]] and [[Anna Carin Olofsson-Zidek]] were held back and had to start several seconds too late. U.S. coach Per Nilsson stated that he had never seen an Olympic biathlon as poorly managed as the February 16 women's race.<ref name=Slot>{{cite news|last=Slot|first=Owen|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/olympics/article7031487.ece|title=The Calamity Games in Vancouver still finding ways to blunder|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=February 18, 2010 | location=London}}</ref><ref name=Error/>
International Biathlon Union (IBU) officials were directing the starts.<ref name=IBU1>{{cite news |last=Ebner |first=David |url=http://www.ctvolympics.ca/biathlon/news/newsid=43761.html#start+gate+issues+cause+chaos+biathlon+courses |title=Start gate issues cause chaos on biathlon courses |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=February 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304041901/http://www.ctvolympics.ca/biathlon/news/newsid%3D43761.html#start+gate+issues+cause+chaos+biathlon+courses |archivedate=March 4, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The incorrect starts were attributed to a Swiss official at the women's start and a Czech official at the men's start. Norbert Baier, technical delegate for the International Biathlon Union, called it the worst day of his career and took full responsibility, stating that the mistakes were their fault.<ref name="IBU1"/> He also noted that similar incidents have previously occurred on the World Cup circuit in Europe. Notably, at last year's World Championships in Pyeongchang, South Korea, several competitors were sent out the wrong way on the first lap.<ref name=IBU2>{{cite news |last=Wright |first=Chris |url=http://www.ctvolympics.ca/biathlon/news/newsid=43751.html#protests+over+start+foul+biathlon |title=Protests over start foul-ups mar biathlon |newspaper=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |date=February 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100312230059/http://www.ctvolympics.ca/biathlon/news/newsid%3D43751.html#protests+over+start+foul+biathlon |archivedate=March 12, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
== Olympic flame ==
The opening ceremony was stalled while organizers recovered from mechanical problems which prevented the pillars forming the cauldron for the torch lighting from completely rising out of the stadium floor as planned. However this was soon fixed as seen in the Closing Ceremony, where they made a joke out of it. An Engineer Mime climbed out of the stage as if he had just fixed it and he pretended to pull it up. [[Speed skater]] [[Catriona Le May Doan]], who was supposed to have lit the 4th pillar, came out from the floor to finally get the chance to light it.<ref name="mishaps">{{cite news|url=http://www.torontosun.com/sports/vancouver2010/news/2010/02/15/12883441-sun.html|title=Mishaps plague games|last=MACKIN|first=BOB |date=February 15, 2010|work=Toronto Sun|accessdate=February 16, 2010}}</ref>
== Transportation ==
After problems with malfunctioning buses and lost drivers delayed spectators trying to go to or return from Olympic venues, the games organizers called in an additional 100 buses and drivers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Glor|first=Jeff|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/02/17/eveningnews/main6217843.shtml|title=Are Vancouver Olympics the Bad Luck Games?|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=February 17, 2010}}</ref> The problematic buses and drivers were contracted from [[Gameday Management]], an American company which had also serviced the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] in [[Salt Lake City]].<ref name="Gameday01">{{cite web|url=http://gamedaymanagement.com/web/about-us/ |title=About Us |publisher=Gameday Management Group |accessdate=May 5, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Representatives of BC bus drivers and companies criticized VANOC for using Gameday and its American drivers instead of local operators, contending that drivers from states such as Texas were not experienced with mountain driving and winter road conditions.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/09/29/bc-olympic-buses.html ''Pro-U.S. bias alleged in Olympic bus contracts'', CBC News British Columbia, September 29, 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003130917/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/09/29/bc-olympic-buses.html |date=October 3, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=TorontoSun-Mackin>{{cite news|last=Mackin|first=Bob|url=http://www.torontosun.com/sports/vancouver2010/news/2010/02/17/12919981.html|title=VANOC stays on defensive|newspaper=[[Toronto Sun]]|date=February 18, 2010}}</ref>
== Own The Podium - 2010 ==
[[Own the Podium|Own the Podium - 2010]], or ''À nous le podium en 2010!'' in French, is a Canadian sport technical program launched in January 2005 to prepare Canada to become the top winter sporting nation in the world by the 2010 Winter Olympics. The main aspect of the scheme which has caused controversy is the priority of Canadian competitors in conducting practice runs of events, particularly at the Whistler Slide Centre, over competitors from other countries.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010|reason="Main aspect" would also need sourcing - didn't Canadians practice on some courses long before the Olympics began?}} A newspaper in the United Kingdom blamed the program for the death of [[Nodar Kumaritashvili]], a luge athlete from Georgia who died on the opening day of the 2010 Winter Olympic Games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-1251006/MARTIN-SAMUEL-Canadas-lust-glory-blame-senseless-tragedy-Nodar-Kumaritashvili.html|title=Daily Mail, Canada's lust for glory is to blame for this senseless tragedy, February 16, 2010 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Samuel | date=February 16, 2010}}</ref> Several of the country's former Olympians have criticized the program as unsportsmanlike,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctvolympics.ca/news-centre/newsid=39525.html |title=The Globe and Mail, The torch expresses what medals can't, February 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216145212/http://www.ctvolympics.ca/news-centre/newsid%3D39525.html |archivedate=February 16, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> while others note that program organizers seem oblivious to principles of good sportsmanship enshrined by the founder of the modern Olympics, [[Pierre de Coubertin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://olympics.fanhouse.com/2010/02/14/canadas-goal-to-own-the-podium-takes-an-early-step-down|title=Canada Takes an Early Step Down in Climb to Own the Podium, February 14, 2010}}</ref> It has been typical in past Olympics for the host nation to allow foreign athletes to train on the courses for a certain amount of time (e.g. the USA allowed Canadian athletes to train in Salt Lake in 2002).{{Citation needed|date=March 2010|reason=Also vague - other teams WERE allowed to practice "for a certain amount of time".}} The amount of time provided to foreign athletes for training in fact met if not exceeded the requirements of each sporting federation.<ref name=trainingtime>{{cite news |last=Morris |first=Him |url=http://www.ctvolympics.ca/news-centre/newsid=8935.html |title=Canada not cheating by limiting access to Olympic venues prior to Games |newspaper=[[Canadian Press]] |date=April 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304122533/http://www.ctvolympics.ca/news-centre/newsid%3D8935.html |archivedate=March 4, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> An [[International Luge Federation]] official stated that more pre-Games training time had been secured than at any previous Olympic Games<ref name="fil">{{cite news |last=Cole |first=Cam |url=https://vancouversun.com/sports/2010wintergames/Column+Whistler+Sliding+Centre+fastest+track+Earth/2732426/story.html |title=Column: The Whistler Sliding Centre is the fastest track on Earth |newspaper=[[Vancouver Sun]] |date=March 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110214085846/http://www.vancouversun.com/sports/2010wintergames/Column%2BWhistler%2BSliding%2BCentre%2Bfastest%2Btrack%2BEarth/2732426/story.html |archivedate=February 14, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Canadian officials also pointed out instances at the [[2002 Winter Olympics|2002]] and [[2006 Winter Olympics|2006]] Olympic Games where the host Organizing Committee restricted access to its own venues; in particular among these, luge athlete [[Jeff Christie]] stated that foreign athletes were given less training time than required at the 2006 Turin Olympics.<ref name="trainingtime"/>
== Canadian women hockey players seen drinking and smoking ==
Some time after winning their gold medal in the finals of the [[Ice hockey at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's hockey tournament]], a 2-0 victory over the United States on February 25, 2010, several members of the Canadian women's hockey team celebrated on the stadium ice while drinking beer and champagne, and smoking cigars. Unbeknownst to the players they were photographed and their celebration was criticized in the media,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://network.nationalpost.com/NP/blogs/fullcomment/archive/2010/02/26/canada-s-women-s-hockey-team-celebrate-with-beer-cigars-ioc-gets-huffy.aspx|title=Canada's Women's Hockey team celebrate with beer, cigars; IOC gets huffy, February 26, 2010}}{{dead link|date=June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.marketwatch.com/vancouverolympics/2010/02/26/canadians%E2%80%99-victory-celebration-questioned/|title=Canadians' victory celebration questioned, February 26, 2010}}</ref> the reason being that smoking and [[drinking in public]] was unbecoming of Olympic athletes, especially while in uniform and in their playing venue. [[Hockey Canada]] issued an apology, although other members of the Olympic community dismissed concerns over the event.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctvolympics.ca/hockey/news/newsid=52689.html |title=Team Canada apologizes for post-game behaviour, February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301185434/http://www.ctvolympics.ca/hockey/news/newsid%3D52689.html |archivedate=March 1, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The IOC considered looking into the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesonline.typepad.com/olympics/2010/02/drinking-to-canadas-success.html |title=Drinking to Canada's success, February 25, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301074115/http://timesonline.typepad.com/olympics/2010/02/drinking-to-canadas-success.html |archivedate=March 1, 2010 }}</ref> Canadian hockey captain [[Hayley Wickenheiser]] said a [[double standard]] was being applied, and that a male athlete would not have been judged so harshly, as was the case with [[Skeleton (sport)|skeleton]] gold medalist [[Jon Montgomery]] and his post race beer consumption.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/olympics/hockey/story/2010/02/26/sp-hockey-women-drinking.html |title=IOC rep downplays women's hockey party: Hockey Canada apologizes for party on ice, February 25, 2010 |work=CBC News |date=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100228015327/http://www.cbc.ca/olympics/hockey/story/2010/02/26/sp-hockey-women-drinking.html |archivedate=February 28, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/blog/the_sporting_blog/entry/view/56759/canadas_jon_montgomery_knows_how_to_party|title=Canada's Jon Montgomery Knows How to Party, February 22, 2010}}</ref>
== Human Rights ==
[[File:Native Warrior Society - Olympic Flag.jpg|thumb|Members of the Native Warriors Society pose with the stolen Winter Olympics flag, while holding a [[Mohawk Warriors Society]] flag. They stole the flag to protest the Olympics, and to honour the death of [[Harriet Nahanee]].<ref name=StolenFlag>{{cite web|author=Native Warrior Society |title=Native Warriors Claim Responsibility for Taking Olympic Flag |url=http://news.infoshop.org/article.php?story=20070309112826215 |publisher=Infoshop News |date=March 7, 2007 |accessdate=February 17, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118230414/http://news.infoshop.org/article.php?story=20070309112826215 |archivedate=November 18, 2011 }}</ref>]]
<!-- If this section becomes more than a few paragraphs, please split it into a new article, with a smaller lead paragraph remaining here
: ''For more details on this topic, see [[Opposition of 2010 Vancouver Olympics]]''
--> Opposition to the 2010 Olympic Games was expressed by various activists, politicians and communities.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jeff |last=Lee |title=Protesters arrested at Olympic flag illumination |url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/westcoastnews/story.html?id=2ae5bf05-2367-4ee0-b08a-3800325f181a |work=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |date=March 13, 2007 |accessdate=July 7, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021220445/http://canada.com/vancouversun/news/westcoastnews/story.html?id=2ae5bf05-2367-4ee0-b08a-3800325f181a# |archive-date=October 21, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== Indigenous people ===
There is opposition to the Olympics amongst some [[indigenous people]] and their supporters. Although the [[Lil'wat]] branch of the St'at'imc Nation is a co-host of the games, a splinter group from the [[Seton Lake First Nation|Seton]] band known as the St'at'imc of Sutikalh, who have also opposed the Cayoosh Ski Resort, fear the Olympics are bringing unwanted tourism and real estate sales to their territory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.warriorpublications.com/?q=node/22|title=Sutikalh Re-occupation Camp}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.dominionpaper.ca/articles/1738 |title=It's all about the Land|publisher=The Dominion}}</ref> On another front, local aboriginal people as well as Canadian [[Inuit]] expressed concern over the choice of an [[inukshuk]] as the symbol of the Games, with some Inuit leaders such as former [[Nunavut]] Commissioner [[Peter Irniq]] stating that the inukshuk is a culturally important symbol to them. He said that the "Inuit never build inuksuit with head, legs and arms. I have seen inuksuit build [sic] more recently, 100 years maybe by non-Inuit in Nunavut, with head, legs and arms. These are not called inuksuit. These are called inunguat, imitation of man."<ref>{{cite news |title=Olympic inukshuk irks Inuit leader |publisher=[[CBC.ca]] Sports |date=April 27, 2005 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2005/04/26/olympic-logo050426.html |accessdate=August 13, 2008}}</ref> Local aboriginal groups also expressed annoyance that the design did not reflect the [[Coast Salish peoples|Coast Salish]] and [[Interior Salish]] native culture from the region the Games are being held in, but rather that of the Inuit, who are indigenous to the Arctic far from Vancouver. One chief, [[Stewart Phillip]], President of the [[Union of British Columbia Indian Chiefs]], also said that the design lacked dignity, comparing it to [[Pac-Man]]. [[Edward John]], Grand Chief of the [[First Nations Summit]], said some native leaders were so upset about the issue they were prepared to walk out of the unveiling ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2005/04/26/Olympiclogo0426.html |title=Vancouver Olympic emblem comes under fire |date=April 27, 2005 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=January 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531002729/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2005/04/26/Olympiclogo0426.html |archivedate=May 31, 2008 }}</ref> The aboriginal governments of the [[Squamish Nation|Squamish]], [[Musqueam Indian Band|Musqueam]], [[Lil'wat First Nation|Lil'wat]] and [[Tsleil-Waututh First Nation|Tsleil-Waututh]] (the "Four Host First Nations"), on whose traditional territory the games are being held, signed a protocol in 2004<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070808160218/http://fourhostfirstnations.com/downloads/4HN_Protocol_Final_Nov%2024.pdf 4HN_Protocol_Final_Nov 24.pub<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> in support of the games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fourhostfirstnations.com/ |title=Four Host First Nations |publisher=Four Host First Nations |date= |accessdate=February 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108042742/http://www.fourhostfirstnations.com/ |archivedate=January 8, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== Protests ===
In 2006, environmental protests at Eagleridge Bluffs in [[West Vancouver]] over the building of a new highway resulted in the arrest of over 20 people, and jail time for two local women, [[Betty Krawczyk]] and [[Harriet Nahanee]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Police move in to end protest on Bluffs.|date=May 29, 2006|publisher=Vancouver Sun|url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=76a51906-0e2f-408e-ba97-ed60f2714c2a&p=1|access-date=February 18, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604124243/http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=76a51906-0e2f-408e-ba97-ed60f2714c2a&p=1#|archive-date=June 4, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eagleridgebluffs.ca/ |title=The Coalition to Save Eagleridge Bluffs at Horseshoe Bay |accessdate=March 28, 2007}}</ref> Harriett Nahanee, an elderly woman, died shortly after incarceration from medical conditions thought to be exacerbated by her time in jail. According to critics, despite claims of the "greenest Olympics" ever, and statements about "sustainability", the 2010 Olympics would leave behind environmental damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emagazine.com/view/?4980|title=Are the Games Really Green?|publisher=E, the Environmental Magazine|accessdate=January 31, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100223191150/http://www.emagazine.com/view/?4980#|archive-date=February 23, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/article-262458/garry-john-and-maude-barlow-2010-olympics-will-leave-legacy-social-environmental-destruction|title=Garry John and Maude Barlow: 2010 Olympics will leave legacy of social, environmental destruction|publisher=[[The Georgia Straight]]|accessdate=January 31, 2010}}</ref>
On Saturday February 13, the first day of the actual Olympic sporting events, windows of [[The Hudson's Bay Company]] (The Bay), an Olympic sponsor, were smashed in downtown Vancouver by protestors.<ref>[https://www.straight.com/article-289546/vancouver/2010-heart-attack-disrupts-vancouver-day-two-winter-olympics/ Olympic Violence]</ref><ref>[http://www.excerptcize.com/2010/02/13/anti-olympic-protests-continue-on-day-2/ Anti-Olympic Protests Continue On Day 2 | Excerptcize<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330204526/http://www.excerptcize.com/2010/02/13/anti-olympic-protests-continue-on-day-2/ |date=March 30, 2010 }}</ref> <ref>[http://sports.ca.msn.com/olympics/article.aspx?cp-documentid=23470742/ Charges laid In Riot] {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Protesters had also vandalized branches of the [[Royal Bank of Canada]], an Olympic sponsor, in Ottawa, Vancouver and Victoria.<ref>{{cite news |title=Anti-2010 vandals hit Ottawa Royal Bank |author=Mackin, B. |date=February 6, 2008 |publisher=24 Hours |url=http://vancouver.24hrs.ca/News/2008/02/07/4831587-sun.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120724142043/http://vancouver.24hrs.ca/News/2008/02/07/4831587-sun.html |archivedate=July 24, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The documentary film ''Five Ring Circus'' outlined reasons behind the protests.<ref>{{cite web |title=Five Ring Circus |url=http://www.thefiveringcircus.com/ |work=Documentary film |year=2007 |accessdate=October 5, 2007}}</ref> and in Helen Jefferson Lenskyj's books ''Olympic Industry Resistance'' (2007) and ''Inside the Olympic Industry'' (2000).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunypress.edu/p-4631-olympic-industry-resistance.aspx; |title=www.sunypress.edu/p-3274-inside-the-olympic-industry.aspx |publisher=Sunypress.edu |date= |accessdate=February 7, 2010}}</ref> Including concerns about the expense to taxpayers, estimated in 2007 to be CAN$580 million.<ref>{{cite news |author=CTV.ca News Staff |title=Vancouver 2010 Olympics to cost $1.6 billion |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070508/vanoc_plan_070508 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021225553/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070508/vanoc_plan_070508 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 21, 2007 |date=May 8, 2007 |publisher=[[CTV Television Network]] |accessdate=July 7, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> After the stock market crash of 2008, there have been increasing concerns that Games-related projects would not meet their economic targets. The Olympic Village development, for example, was originally intended to make a profit, but at least one critic estimates it will be millions in debt. Olympic organizers have not commented on this estimate.<ref>{{cite news |first=Miro |last=Cernetig |title=Olympic Village finances getting scary for taxpayers |url=https://vancouversun.com/business/Column+Olympic+Village+finances+getting+scary+taxpayers/1141738/story.html |date=January 5, 2009 |publisher=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |accessdate=January 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720061500/http://www.vancouversun.com/business/Column%2BOlympic%2BVillage%2Bfinances%2Bgetting%2Bscary%2Btaxpayers/1141738/story.html |archivedate=July 20, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Also protested was the displacement of low-income residents and criminalization of the poor and homeless through policies designed to make the city appear cleaner.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sfbayview.com/2009/anti-olympics-movement-targeted-some-15-visu-joint-intelligence-group-visits-in-48-hours/ }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.accuracy.org/newsrelease.php?articleId=2175# |title=Protesting the Olympics? - Institute for Public Accuracy (IPA)<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=February 18, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612231056/http://accuracy.org/newsrelease.php?articleId=2175# |archive-date=June 12, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>[http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/308028,olympics-take-a-walk-on-the-wild-side-in-vancouver.html Olympics? Take a walk on the wild side in Vancouver - Feature : Sports<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.timesargus.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20070606%2FSPORTS%2F706060329%2F1004%2FSPORTS# |title=Olympic games evict millions: Times Argus Online<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=November 9, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304191038/http://www.timesargus.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20070606%2FSPORTS%2F706060329%2F1004%2FSPORTS# |archive-date=March 4, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><!-- - this is a sentence fragment --> Critics also anticipated an increase in [[human trafficking]] for the purpose of forced prostitution.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thetyee.ca/News/2008/09/04/HumanTraffic/ |title=The Tyee – Will Olympics Be Magnet for Human Traffickers? |publisher=Thetyee.ca |date=September 4, 2008 |accessdate=February 7, 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.vancouverobserver.com/politics/commentary/2010/02/02/human-trafficking-alive-and-well-2010-olympics Human Trafficking Alive and Well for the 2010 Olympics | The Vancouver Observer - Vancouver Olympics News Blogs Events Reviews<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[https://montrealgazette.com/sports/2010wintergames/sports/2010wintergames/Vancouver+Olympics+failing+curb+trafficking+group/2542883/story.html Vancouver Olympics get an 'F' for failing to curb sex trafficking: group<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214004546/http://www.montrealgazette.com/sports/2010wintergames/sports/2010wintergames/Vancouver%2BOlympics%2Bfailing%2Bcurb%2Btrafficking%2Bgroup/2542883/story.html |date=February 14, 2010 }}</ref> As with Vancouver's Expo 86 which led to the displacement of hundreds of residents in the Downtown Eastside area of the city, or Expo 2010 where 18,000 families were displaced from the Shanghai area, the 2010 Olympics had a similar effect of displacing and criminalizing poor communities, while corporate sponsors of the 'games' made billions and billions of dollars of profit at the expense of peoples' lives and homes.<ref>https://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/expo-86-when-vancouver-wooed-the-world-30-photos-30-years-later</ref>
